question: According to 1 John 3:10, what is the distinction between the children of God and the children of the Devil?

options.text: Their appearance and their wealth.
Anyone who does not do what is right or loves his brother is not of God.
Their membership in a particular religious organization.
The number of miracles they can do.

explanation: John makes it clear that practicing righteousness and loving one's brothers are the defining characteristics of those who are God's children.
verseTextContent: The children of God and the children of the Devil are evident by this fact: Whoever does not practice righteousness does not originate with God, nor does the one who does not love his brother.

question: What statement about God is especially emphasized at 1 John 4:8 and 4:16?

options.text: God is all-powerful.
God is love.
God is a jealous God.
God is the Judge of all the earth.

explanation: One central message of 1 John is the revelation of God's nature as love.
verseTextContent: Whoever does not love has not come to know God, because God is love.

question: What does John mean when he speaks at 1 John 5:16-17 of a "sin that attracts to death" for which we should not pray?

options.text: All sorts of accidental sin.
A willful, unrepentant sin, often against the holy spirit, that is unforgivable.
The sins committed by the disbelievers.
Small everyday mistakes.

explanation: John distinguishes between sins for which forgiveness is possible and "a sin that attracts death", the latter likely referring to a conscious, hardened, unrepentant attitude of sin, often understood as sin against the holy spirit and without real repentance, making intercession useless.
verseTextContent: If anyone catches sight of his brother committing a sin that does not incur death, he will ask, and God will give life to him, yes, to those not committing sin that incurs death. There is a sin that does incur death. It is concerning that sin that I do not tell him to make request. All unrighteousness is sin, and yet there is a sin that does not incur death.

question: At 1 John 2:18-19, John speaks of "antichrist" and "many antichrists", and what is the primary meaning of the term "antichrist" in this context?

options.text: To a single, future political horror figure.
To persons who deny Christ, distort his teachings, or falsely claim to be or represent Christ, and who have come out of the community of believers.
To the Roman Empire as a persecutor of Christians.
To demons and evil spirits.

explanation: John uses the term "antichrist" to describe those who oppose Christ by denying that Jesus is the Christ or the relationship between the Father and the Son, and he speaks of both a general "spirit of the antichrist" and "many antichrists" who were active in his day, often from the Christian community, but who turned away from true teaching.
verseTextContent: Young children, it is the last hour, and just as you have heard that the antichrist is coming, even now many antichrists have appeared, from which fact we know that it is the last hour. They went out from us, but they were not of our sort; for if they had been of our sort, they would have remained with us. But they went out so that it might be shown that not all are of our sort.

question: To whom is the apostle John writing this short letter?

options.text: To Gaius, his beloved friend.
To "the chosen lady and her children".
To the seven congregations in Asia.
To Theophilus.

explanation: John's second letter is addressed to "the chosen lady and her children", but it is controversial whether this refers to a literal woman and her family or symbolically to a specific Christian congregation and its members.
verseTextContent: The older man to the chosen lady and to her children, whom I truly love, and not only I but also all those who have come to know the truth,

question: What is the commandment that the recipients "have heard from the beginning" to walk in, according to John?

options.text: To love the world.
To love each other.
To honor the prophets.
To keep the law of Moses.

explanation: John emphasizes the importance of mutual love as a basic commandment that Christians have received from the beginning and that should govern their life course.
verseTextContent: So now I request you, lady, that we love one another. (I am writing you, not a new commandment, but one that we had from the beginning.) And this is what love means, that we go on walking according to his commandments. This is the commandment, just as you have heard from the beginning, that you should go on walking in it.

question: What is John's strong warning about in this letter?

options.text: Before being persecuted by the Roman authorities.
From the deceivers and those who do not confess that Jesus Christ came in the flesh (antichrists).
The Commission has already taken a number of measures to combat the situation in the Mediterranean.
Excessive enthusiasm in the faith.

explanation: A major concern of John in this letter is the warning against misleading teachers ('deceivers' and 'antichrists') who deny the basic truth about Jesus Christ, especially his incarnation.
verseTextContent: For many deceivers have gone out into the world, those not acknowledging Jesus Christ as coming in the flesh. This is the deceiver and the antichrist.

question: What counsel does John give regarding dealing with someone who "does not abide in the teaching of the Christ" and does not bring that teaching?

options.text: To admonish him kindly and to try to convert him.
Not to take him in and not to say hello.
To debate with him publicly to expose his errors.
Pray for him, but avoid any further contact.

explanation: John gives clear instructions not to entertain such false teachers or to greet them, so as not to share in their wicked works and to protect the purity of the congregation.
verseTextContent: Everyone who pushes ahead and does not remain in the teaching of the Christ does not have God. The one who does remain in this teaching is the one who has both the Father and the Son. If anyone comes to you and does not bring this teaching, do not receive him into your homes or say a greeting to him. For the one who says a greeting to him is a sharer in his wicked works.

question: What is the "truth" that, according to John, "remains in us and will be with us forever"?

options.text: A philosophical idea about the universe.
The whole of Christian teaching, especially the truth about Jesus Christ and his commandments.
Personal revelations and prophetic revelations.
The traditions of the elders.

explanation: In the context of the letters of John, "the truth" refers to the apostolic teaching about the person and work of Jesus Christ, God's commandments (especially the commandment of love) and the resulting way of life.
verseTextContent: because of the truth that remains in us and will be with us forever.

question: John expresses the hope of speaking "face to face" with the recipients. (Verse 12) What does this indicate about the kind of "chosen lady" to whom he writes?

options.text: That it is definitely a heavenly, invisible entity.
That it was likely a specific person or a local congregation he could attend personally.
That he only meant a metaphorical, spiritual community.
That he's expecting a vision or a dream.

explanation: The desire for a personal meeting (to speak face to face) suggests that John was thinking of an attainable, real reception, whether it be an individual with his family or a specific household congregation.
verseTextContent: Although I have many things to write to you, I do not want to do so with paper and ink, but I am hoping to come to you and to speak with you face-to-face, so that your joy may be in full measure.

question: What problem in the congregation at Corinth did Paul first address, namely divisions and the succession of human leaders?

options.text: Immoral conduct in the congregation.
Disputes over eating meat sacrificed to idols.
For some say, "I follow Paul, " others", I follow Apollos, " or "I follow Cephas, " or "I follow Christ".
Abuse of spiritual gifts at the Lord's Supper.

explanation: Paul urged the Corinthians to be wary of the divisions and divisions that had arisen among them because they were following different human teachers rather than maintaining their unity in Christ.
verseTextContent: Now I urge you, brothers, through the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you should all speak in agreement and that there should be no divisions among you, but that you may be completely united in the same mind and in the same line of thought. For some from the house of Chloʹe have informed me regarding you, my brothers, that there are dissensions among you. What I mean is this, that each one of you says: “I belong to Paul,” “But I to A·polʹlos,” “But I to Ceʹphas,” “But I to Christ.”

question: What important Christian hope and teaching does Paul discuss in detail in 1 Corinthians chapter 15?

options.text: The baptism of the Holy Spirit.
The resurrection of the dead.
The Millennium and the Kingdom of God.
The role of angels in the plan of salvation.

explanation: Chapter 15 of 1 Corinthians is one of the most basic accounts of Christ's resurrection and the resulting hope of believers.
verseTextContent: Now if it is being preached that Christ has been raised from the dead, how is it that some among you say there is no resurrection of the dead? If, indeed, there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not been raised up. But if Christ has not been raised up, our preaching is certainly in vain, and your faith is also in vain.

question: What counsel does Paul give about marriage and singleness in 1 Corinthians chapter 7?

options.text: That all Christians should remain single.
It is good for a man to remain single and to be united in the service of the Lord. But if anyone is married, he is allowed to marry because of sexual immorality.
That only widows and widowers can remarry.
That divorce is allowed for any reason.

explanation: Paul recommends singleness as a way of serving the Lord without distraction, but he recognizes marriage as a God-given framework and a means of combating sexual immorality.
verseTextContent: Now concerning the things about which you wrote, it is better for a man not to touch a woman; but because of the prevalence of sexual immorality, let each man have his own wife and each woman have her own husband.

question: What picture does Paul use in 1 Corinthians chapter 12 to describe the unity and diversity of gifts in the Christian congregation?

options.text: The image of a temple with many stones.
The image of the human body with many different limbs.
The image of an army with different units.
The image of a field with different plants.

explanation: Paul compares the congregation to a body made up of many members, each having a unique function given by the holy spirit, and all of them are necessary and dependent on one another for the functioning of the whole body.
verseTextContent: For just as the body is one but has many members, and all the members of that body, although many, are one body, so too is the Christ.

question: At 1 Corinthians 11, Paul rebukes the Corinthians for their conduct at the Lord's Evening Meal.

options.text: They used the wrong bread and the wrong wine.
Some came early, eating and drinking excessively, leaving little to others who came later or were poor, and divisions arose.
They celebrated the dinner too often.
Only the elders attended the celebration.

explanation: The gathering of the Corinthians for the Lord's Supper was marked by divisions and disregard, with the richer members eating their brought meals before the poorer ones arrived, leading to hunger and intoxication among the others, and missing the real purpose of the common meal in honor of Christ.
verseTextContent: When you come together in one place, it is not really to eat the Lord’s Evening Meal. For when you eat it, each one takes his own evening meal beforehand, so that one is hungry but another is intoxicated. Do you not have houses for eating and drinking? Or do you despise the congregation of God and make those who have nothing feel ashamed? What can I say to you? Should I commend you? In this I do not commend you.

question: What principle did Paul set forth at 1 Corinthians 9 when defending his right to financial support from the congregations, although he often waived it?

options.text: That the apostles are not entitled to support.
That those who sow spiritual things have the right to reap material things (i.e., receive support), just as a worker is worth his wages.
That only apostles from Jerusalem should be supported.
That financial support should be provided only in the form of alms.

explanation: Paul argued, using examples from everyday life (soldier, winemaker, shepherd) and the Mosaic Law (the roaring bull does not bind the mouth), that those who work in the service of the gospel have a right to material support from those they serve, but he himself often waived that right in order not to hinder the gospel.
verseTextContent: What soldier ever serves at his own expense? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat of its fruit? Or who shepherds a flock and does not partake of some of the milk of the flock?

question: At 2 Corinthians 1:3-4, what does Paul describe as the source of all comfort that enables us to comfort others in their tribulation?

options.text: Human wisdom and philosophy.
The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of compassion and the God of all comfort,
The support of the congregation.
Avoiding trouble.

explanation: Paul praises God as the ultimate source of comfort and mercy, and the comfort God gives believers in their own trials equips them to help others in similar situations.
verseTextContent: Praised be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of tender mercies and the God of all comfort, who comforts us in all our trials so that we may be able to comfort others in any sort of trial with the comfort that we receive from God.

question: At 2 Corinthians 5:17, with what picture does Paul describe the change that a person experiences when he is "in union with Christ"?

options.text: It's like a newly planted tree.
He is a "new creation"; the old things have passed away, and, look! new things have come into existence.
He's like a runner who wins a race.
He's like a soldier equipped for battle.

explanation: The union with Christ brings about a radical transformation, which Paul describes as a "new creation" in which the old sinful life ends and a new life begins in Christ.
verseTextContent: Therefore, if anyone is in union with Christ, he is a new creation; the old things passed away; look! new things have come into existence.

question: What admonition does Paul give to the Corinthians at 2 Corinthians 6:14: "Do not become unevenly yoked with unbelievers"?

options.text: Do not enter into business relations with non-Christians.
To avoid spiritual compromise, guard against close, binding associations (such as marriage or very close partnerships) with people who do not share the faith in Christ.
Not to live in cities where many unbelievers live.
Avoid making friends with people outside the congregation.

explanation: Paul warns against close, intimate relationships (symbolized by the "yeast") with unbelievers, since the basic values, goals, and loyalties of believers and unbelievers are incompatible and can lead to spiritual conflicts and compromises.
verseTextContent: Do not become unevenly yoked with unbelievers. For what fellowship do righteousness and lawlessness have? Or what sharing does light have with darkness?

question: What does Paul mean by the "thorn in the flesh" given to him, as mentioned at 2 Corinthians 12:7?

options.text: A literal physical injury from a thorn.
A persistent, tormenting trial or affliction (perhaps physical illness, persecution, or false apostles) that kept him humble.
Constant doubts about his post office.
A lack of financial support from the Corinthians.

explanation: Although the exact nature of the "thorn in the flesh" is not specified, it was a constant, painful test that prevented Paul from exalting himself because of the extraordinary revelations he had received.
verseTextContent: just because of receiving such extraordinary revelations. To keep me from becoming overly exalted, I was given a thorn in the flesh, an angel of Satan, to keep slapping me, so that I might not be overly exalted.

question: In 2 Corinthians chapters 8 and 9, Paul speaks in detail about a collection for needy saints.

options.text: That everyone has to give a fixed percentage of their income.
For God loves a cheerful giver, and each one must give as he has purposed in his heart, not grudgingly or under compulsion.
That only wealthy Christians should contribute to the collection.
That the collection was primarily used to support the apostles.

explanation: Paul emphasizes that Christian giving should be from a willing and joyful heart, not a prescribed amount, but a loving-motivated generosity that results from a personal decision.
verseTextContent: Let each one do just as he has resolved in his heart, not grudgingly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver.

question: What is the main argument that Paul makes for the authenticity of his apostolate, though not in human letters of recommendation? (2 Corinthians 3:1-3) What is the main argument that Paul makes for the authenticity of his apostolate?

options.text: His rhetorical superiority and wisdom.
The Corinthians themselves were his letter of recommendation, as their faith and life changed by his ministry, a letter of Christ, written by the Spirit of God.
His direct descent from the original twelve apostles.
The great number of miracles he has performed publicly.

explanation: Paul argues that he does not need any external letters of recommendation, since the existence and faith of the congregation in Corinth itself is the best evidence of its God-approved apostolic office, like a letter written by Christ through Paul's ministry, written by God's spirit into their hearts.
verseTextContent: Are we starting to recommend ourselves again? Or do we need, like some men, letters of recommendation to you or from you? You yourselves are our letter, inscribed on our hearts and known and being read by all mankind. For you are shown to be a letter of Christ written by us as ministers, inscribed not with ink but with the spirit of a living God, not on stone tablets but on fleshly tablets, on hearts.

question: To whom does Peter address his first letter, as mentioned at 1 Peter 1:1?

options.text: To the apostles at Jerusalem.
To the "chosen ones" who are scattered as temporary residents in Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia and Bithynia.
To the Roman citizens of the capital.
To all the Jews in the Diaspora.

explanation: Peter writes to Christians living in various provinces of Asia Minor who were often regarded as foreigners and persecuted.
verseTextContent: Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ, to the temporary residents scattered about in Ponʹtus, Ga·laʹti·a, Cap·pa·doʹci·a, Asia, and Bi·thynʹi·a, to those chosen

question: What admonition does Peter give Christians at 1 Peter 2:17 regarding all kinds of people and the brotherhood?

options.text: To honor only the brothers of faith.
to honor all sorts of men, to love the whole brotherhood, to fear God, to honor the king.
To distance oneself from all the people who do not believe.
First of all, honor the king and the authorities.

explanation: Peter gives a comprehensive instruction for Christian social conduct: Respect for all men, special love for the Christian community, reverence for God, and proper respect for secular authorities.
verseTextContent: Honor men of all sorts, have love for the whole association of brothers, be in fear of God, honor the king.

question: According to 1 Peter 1:3-4, what hope do Christians have in the resurrection of Jesus Christ?

options.text: The hope of wealth and prosperity in this life.
A living hope for an incorruptible, unblemished, and incorruptible inheritance that is kept in the heavens.
The hope of political liberation of Rome.
The hope of performing miracles like Jesus did.

explanation: By God's mercy and the resurrection of Jesus, Christians have a sure and living hope of an everlasting inheritance in heaven that cannot be corrupted or stained by sin.
verseTextContent: Praised be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, for according to his great mercy he gave us a new birth to a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead, to an incorruptible and undefiled and unfading inheritance. It is reserved in the heavens for you,

question: According to 1 Peter 4:12-13, how should Christians react when they face fiery trials and sufferings for Christ's sake?

options.text: Despair and give up their faith.
Do not be surprised, but rejoice because you share in the sufferings of Christ, so that you may rejoice with joy when his glory is revealed.
Practice revenge on those who persecute them.
Try to avoid suffering at all costs.

explanation: Peter encourages believers not to view suffering for Christ's sake as something unusual but as an opportunity to rejoice and share in Christ's sufferings, which will lead to great joy at his return.
verseTextContent: Beloved ones, do not be surprised about the fiery trials that you are experiencing, as though something strange were happening to you. On the contrary, go on rejoicing over the extent to which you are sharers in the sufferings of the Christ, so that you may rejoice and be overjoyed also during the revelation of his glory.

question: What is the "precious cornerstone" mentioned by Peter at 1 Peter 2:6-8, which is a foundation of faith for some and a "stumbling block" for others?

options.text: The Law of Moses.
Jesus Christ himself.
The temple in Jerusalem.
The apostle Peter as the rock of the congregation.

explanation: Peter quotes Old Testament prophecies and applies them to Jesus Christ, who to those who believe in him is the chosen and precious cornerstone of God's spiritual house, but to those who reject him he becomes a stumbling block and a stumbling block.
verseTextContent: For it says in Scripture: “Look! I am laying in Zion a chosen stone, a precious foundation cornerstone, and no one exercising faith in it will ever be disappointed.” It is to you, therefore, that he is precious, because you are believers; but to those not believing, “the stone that the builders rejected, this has become the chief cornerstone” and “a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense.” They are stumbling because they are disobedient to the word. To this very end they were appointed.

question: What admonition does Peter give to believers at 2 Peter 1:5-7, to add various virtues to their faith?

options.text: Only knowledge and wisdom.
to add to their faith virtue, knowledge, self - control, endurance, godly devotion, brotherly affection and love.
Wealth and prestige in the world.
The ability to work miracles.

explanation: Peter urges Christians to make a serious effort to complement and strengthen their faith with a series of godly qualities that are essential for a fruitful Christian life.
verseTextContent: For this very reason, put forth all earnest effort to supply to your faith virtue, to your virtue knowledge, to your knowledge self-control, to your self-control endurance, to your endurance godly devotion, to your godly devotion brotherly affection, to your brotherly affection love.

question: What is Peter's strong warning about in chapter 2 of his second letter?

options.text: From persecution by the Roman government.
false prophets and false teachers who introduce corrupt sects and exploit the faithful.
Before natural disasters and famines.
Too strict in keeping the law.

explanation: A major concern of Peter in his second letter is the warning against false teachers within the congregation who secretly spread destructive teachings, promote immorality, and abuse believers for their own ends.
verseTextContent: However, there also came to be false prophets among the people, as there will also be false teachers among you. These will quietly bring in destructive sects, and they will even disown the owner who bought them, bringing speedy destruction upon themselves.

question: What does Peter say about the prophetic words of the Scriptures at 2 Peter 1:20-21?

options.text: That they are the result of human interpretation and speculation.
that prophecy of Scripture does not come from any private interpretation, but that men were speaking as God had commanded them, being moved by the Holy Spirit.
That most prophecies have already been fulfilled and have no further meaning.
That prophecies can only be understood by specially trained theologians.

explanation: Peter emphasizes the divine origin of Bible prophecy, which is not the result of human inventions but was uttered by men inspired by the holy spirit and guided by God.
verseTextContent: For you know this first, that no prophecy of Scripture springs from any private interpretation. For prophecy was at no time brought by man’s will, but men spoke from God as they were moved by holy spirit.

question: At 2 Peter 3:9, what reason does Peter give for Jehovah's delay in his day?

options.text: Because Jehovah is indecisive.
Because Jehovah is patient and does not want anyone to be destroyed but wants all to come to repentance.
Because the time for judgment has not yet been set by the angels.
Because people aren't bad enough yet.

explanation: Peter explains that Jehovah's apparent hesitation is not based on slowness but on his patience and desire that as many people as possible take up the opportunity for repentance and salvation.
verseTextContent: Jehovah is not slow concerning his promise, as some people consider slowness, but he is patient with you because he does not desire anyone to be destroyed but desires all to attain to repentance.

question: At 2 Peter 1:16-18, what event in Jesus' life does Peter mention as confirming the "prophecy" of which he was an eyewitness?

options.text: The miracle of bread multiplication.
The transfiguration of Jesus on a high mountain where he heard God's voice.
The resurrection of Lazarus.
Jesus ascended into heaven.

explanation: Peter is referring to the transfiguration of Jesus, when he, together with James and John, witnessed the glory of Jesus and heard God's voice confirm Jesus as his beloved Son.
verseTextContent: No, it was not by following artfully contrived false stories that we made known to you the power and presence of our Lord Jesus Christ, but rather, we were eyewitnesses of his magnificence. For he received from God the Father honor and glory when words such as these were conveyed to him by the magnificent glory: “This is my Son, my beloved, whom I myself have approved.” Yes, these words we heard coming from heaven while we were with him in the holy mountain.

question: How does Peter describe the end of the present "heaven and earth" on "Jehovah's day", and what awaits believers according to 2 Peter 3:10-13?

options.text: A gradual improvement of the world through human efforts.

The heavens will pass away with a roar, and the elements will be dissolved before the blaze, and the earth and all that is on it will be exposed. But there are new heavens and a new earth awaiting the believers, in which righteousness will dwell.
An eternal continuation of the present condition under God's improved rule.
The destruction of the wicked alone, while the physical earth remains intact.

explanation: Peter speaks of a dramatic end to the present system of things ("heaven and earth") that will be cleansed or dissolved by fire, but this judgment will be followed by the creation of "new heavens and a new earth" that will be marked by righteousness, a hope that Christians await.
verseTextContent: But Jehovah’s day will come as a thief, in which the heavens will pass away with a roar, but the elements being intensely hot will be dissolved, and earth and the works in it will be exposed.

question: According to Ephesians 2:8-9, what is the basis for Christians' salvation?

options.text: Only by good works and keeping commandments.
It is by grace through faith and not by works, so that no one can boast.
Through descent and tradition.
Through philosophical knowledge and wisdom.

explanation: Paul emphasizes that salvation is a gift of God and is by faith received by undeserved kindness.
verseTextContent: By this undeserved kindness you have been saved through faith, and this is not of your own doing; rather, it is God’s gift. No, it is not a result of works, so that no one should have grounds for boasting.

question: What illustration does Paul use at Ephesians 6:11-17 to encourage Christians to stand firm against the Devil's machinations?

options.text: The image of a growing tree.
The complete armor of God.
The image of a runner in a race.
The image of a temple being built.

explanation: Paul urges Christians to put on "the complete suit of armor from God", which consists of various parts, such as the belt of truth, the breastplate of righteousness, the shield of faith, etc., in order to stand in the spiritual fight against wicked spirit forces.
verseTextContent: Put on the complete suit of armor from God so that you may be able to stand firm against the crafty acts of the Devil;

question: According to Ephesians 1:9-10, what is God's "administration in the fullness of the appointed times"?

options.text: The destruction of the earth by fire.
to gather together again all things in Christ, both those in heaven and those on earth.
The establishment of a worldwide political system under Christian leadership.
The collection of all the world's riches for God's people.

explanation: God's counsel and administration is to bring together again and harmoniously all things in the universe, both in heaven and on earth, under the authority and direction of Christ at the time appointed by him.
verseTextContent: by making known to us the sacred secret of his will. It is according to his good pleasure that he himself purposed for an administration at the full limit of the appointed times, to gather all things together in the Christ, the things in the heavens and the things on the earth. Yes, in him

question: What is the purpose of the "hope" to which Christians are called, as emphasized at Ephesians 4:4-6?

options.text: To pursue individual goals and dreams.
to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace, since there is one body, one spirit, one Lord, one faith, one baptism, one God and Father of all.
To gain material blessings and health.
To separate themselves from other religious groups.

explanation: Paul exhorts believers to be united in basic truths that are common: there is only one body (the congregation), one spirit (the holy spirit), one common hope, one Lord (Jesus Christ), one faith, one baptism, and one God.
verseTextContent: One body there is, and one spirit, just as you were called to the one hope of your calling; one Lord, one faith, one baptism; one God and Father of all, who is over all and through all and in all.

question: At Ephesians 5:32, Paul speaks of marriage as a "sacred secret" in connection with what deeper truth?

options.text: The creation of Adam and Eve.
Christ and the congregation.
The relationship between parents and children.
The uniqueness of human love.

explanation: Paul explains that the unity and relationship in marriage is an illustration of the deep, loving and inseparable relationship between Christ (the Bridegroom) and his congregation (the Bride), which is the "sacred secret" of Christ's congregation.
verseTextContent: “For this reason a man will leave his father and his mother and he will stick to his wife, and the two will be one flesh.” This sacred secret is great. Now I am speaking about Christ and the congregation.

question: What is the "cornerstone" (or "cornerstone") upon which the Christian congregation is built as "a holy temple to Jehovah", as described at Ephesians 2:20-22?

options.text: The apostle Peter.
Christ Jesus himself.
The foundation of the twelve apostles of Israel.
The Law of Moses and the Prophets.

explanation: The congregation is represented as a spiritual building, or holy temple, built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets. The key cornerstone (or head of the corner) that holds and aligns the entire building is Christ Jesus himself.
verseTextContent: and you have been built up on the foundation of the apostles and prophets, while Christ Jesus himself is the foundation cornerstone. In union with him the whole building, being harmoniously joined together, is growing into a holy temple for Jehovah. In union with him you too are being built up together into a place for God to inhabit by spirit.

question: According to Psalm 23:1, who is the shepherd of the psalmist who will lack nothing?

options.text: King David
Jehovah
An Angel
Moses

explanation: Psalm 23, one of the most well-known psalms, begins with the confident statement: "Jehovah is my Shepherd; I shall lack nothing".
verseTextContent: A melody of David. 23 Jehovah is my Shepherd. I will lack nothing.

question: What does the psalmist praise at Psalm 19:1 (verse 2) as "telling the glory of God"?

options.text: The wisdom of kings.
The sky.
The strength of the armies.
The works of men.

explanation: The psalm opens with the statement that creation, especially the heavens, speak without words of God's glory and creative power.
verseTextContent: To the director. A melody of David. 19 The heavens are declaring the glory of God;The skies above proclaim the work of his hands.

question: According to Psalm 1:1-2, what is the source of happiness and success?

options.text: Great wealth and honor.
To have his delight in Jehovah's law and to read it in a quiet voice day and night.
Having lots of friends and influential contacts.

That he boasted of the power of the cross to defeat enemies.
That the torture stake is a symbol of Christian superiority.

explanation: Paul rejects all selfishness, whether it be on the basis of descent, works of law, or human wisdom. His only reason for glory is the work of Christ's redemption on the torture stake. This death of Christ radically changed his attitude toward the world: the world lost its seductive power over him and he stopped seeking the world's recognition.
verseTextContent: But may I never boast, except in the torture stake of our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom the world has been put to death with regard to me and I with regard to the world.

question: Despite his own imprisonment, what repeated admonition does Paul give in his letter to the Philippians?

options.text: Worrying about the future.
Always rejoice in the Lord.
Living strictly by the law.
The acquisition of material goods.

explanation: A prominent theme of the Philippians letter is the joy in Christ, which Paul stresses even though he himself is in prison.
verseTextContent: Finally, my brothers, continue rejoicing in the Lord. It is not troublesome for me to write the same things to you, and it is for your safety.

question: According to Philippians 4:13, what was the source of Paul's strength to endure all things?

options.text: His own willpower and discipline.
The One who gives him strength (Christ).
The support of the congregations.
Positive thinking.

explanation: Paul testifies that he has learned to endure in all circumstances, whether in abundance or in want. For his strength is not his own, but that of Christ, who strengthens him.
verseTextContent: For all things I have the strength through the one who gives me power.

question: According to Philippians 2:5-8, what humble attitude of Christ should the Philippians imitate?

options.text: His ability to work miracles.

Though in the form of God, he did not think of a violent takeover to be equal to God, but he belittled himself, took on the form of a slave, became like man, and humbled himself to death on the torture stake.
His desire to be honored by all men.
His determination to punish his enemies.

explanation: Paul presents Christ as the ultimate model of humility, who, though of divine nature, gave up his heavenly glory, became man, and served others to the utmost obedience, the death on the cross.
verseTextContent: Keep this mental attitude in you that was also in Christ Jesus, who, although he was existing in God’s form, did not even consider the idea of trying to be equal to God. No, but he emptied himself and took a slave’s form and became human. More than that, when he came as a man, he humbled himself and became obedient to the point of death, yes, death on a torture stake.

question: What counsel does Paul give the Philippians in chapter 4, verse 8, to correct their thinking?

options.text: To their worries and fears to find solutions.
To all that is true, that is of good interest, that is righteous, that is chaste, that is lovable, that is well spoken of, and if there is any virtue or praiseworthy thing.
To learn from the mistakes and weaknesses of others.
To material goals and worldly success.

explanation: Paul emphasizes the importance of meditating on things that are positive, upbuilding, and godly. Meditating on what is true, righteous, pure, lovable, and praiseworthy will promote inner peace and spiritual health.
verseTextContent: Finally, brothers, whatever things are true, whatever things are of serious concern, whatever things are righteous, whatever things are chaste, whatever things are lovable, whatever things are well-spoken-of, whatever things are virtuous, and whatever things are praiseworthy, continue considering these things.

question: At Philippians 3:7-8, Paul writes that he considered all things that had previously seemed to him to be gains (such as his Jewish ancestry and legal righteousness) as "loss" and "destruction".

options.text: Because these things didn't bring him any more social upliftment.
because of the surpassing power of knowing Christ Jesus his Lord, so that we might gain and be established in him, not by our own righteousness, but by faith in him.
Because he was disappointed in his former Jewish brothers.
Because he had adopted a new, simpler philosophy of life.

explanation: For Paul, all the advantages and achievements of Judaism were nothing to him compared with the pricelessness of knowing Christ Jesus and being declared righteous by God through faith in him.
verseTextContent: Yet, the things that were gains to me, I have considered loss on account of the Christ. What is more, I do indeed also consider all things to be loss on account of the excelling value of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord. For his sake I have taken the loss of all things and I consider them as a lot of refuse, that I may gain Christ and be found in union with him, not because of my own righteousness from following the Law, but because of the righteousness that is through faith in Christ, the righteousness from God based on faith.

question: What two companions of Paul are highlighted at Philippians 2:19-30 as examples of unselfish dedication and service to Christ and his brothers?

options.text: Luke and Demas.
Timothy and Epaphroditus.
Barnabas and Mark.
Silas and Titus.

explanation: Paul commends Timothy for his genuine interest in Philippians' welfare and his tried-and-tested willingness to serve.
verseTextContent: Now I am hoping in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you shortly, so that I may be encouraged when I receive news about you. For I have no one else of a disposition like his who will genuinely care for your concerns. For all the others are seeking their own interests, not those of Jesus Christ. But you know the proof he gave of himself, that like a child with a father he slaved with me to advance the good news.

question: According to Colossians 1:15-17, who is "the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation", through whom all things were created?

options.text: The Holy Spirit.
Jesus Christ, please.
The apostle Paul.
Adam, the first man.

explanation: Paul describes Jesus Christ as the exact representation of the invisible God and as the one who existed before all creation and through whom and for whom all things in heaven and on earth were created.
verseTextContent: He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation; because by means of him all other things were created in the heavens and on the earth, the things visible and the things invisible, whether they are thrones or lordships or governments or authorities. All other things have been created through him and for him. Also, he is before all other things, and by means of him all other things were made to exist,

question: What counsel does Paul give to the Colossians at Colossians chapter 3, verses 1-2, to correct their minds after they have been resurrected with Christ?

options.text: To earthly riches and pleasures.
to focus on the things above, where Christ is seated at the right hand of God, not on the things on earth.
To the political liberation of Rome.
To keep the Mosaic Law.

explanation: Since believers have been spiritually resurrected with him through faith in Christ, Paul urges them to focus their thoughts and aspirations on heavenly realities and on Christ rather than on earthly things passing away.
verseTextContent: If, however, you were raised up with the Christ, go on seeking the things above, where the Christ is seated at the right hand of God. Keep your minds fixed on the things above, not on the things on the earth.

question: What kind of misleading teachings does Paul warn the Colossians of in Colossians chapter 2, verses 8, and 16-18?

options.text: Before studying Greek literature.

From philosophy and empty deception according to the tradition of men, the elementary things of the world, and from judging concerning food, drink, feasts, new moons, or sabbaths, and from a hypocrisy which worships angels.
Excessive joy and gratitude.
Before preaching the gospel to the Gentiles.

explanation: Paul warns the Colossians against various false teachings that undermine their freedom in Christ, including human philosophies not based on Christ, the observance of Jewish law as a necessity for salvation, and a mystical form of worship that included angel worship.
verseTextContent: Look out that no one takes you captive by means of the philosophy and empty deception according to human tradition, according to the elementary things of the world and not according to Christ;

question: What exhortation does Paul give at Colossians 3:12-14 regarding the qualities that Christians should wear, and what should be held together?

options.text: Strength, power and authority, held together by discipline.

the tender affections of compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and long - suffering, tolerating one another and forgiving one another freely, and above all this love is the perfect bond of union.
Wisdom, knowledge and intelligence, held together by education.
Law-abiding, tradition and obedience, bound together by fear.

explanation: As God's chosen ones, Christians are to develop a series of godly qualities, such as mercy, kindness, humility, etc. The most important quality that binds all of these together and perfectes them is love.
verseTextContent: Accordingly, as God’s chosen ones, holy and loved, clothe yourselves with the tender affections of compassion, kindness, humility, mildness, and patience. Continue putting up with one another and forgiving one another freely even if anyone has a cause for complaint against another. Just as Jehovah freely forgave you, you must also do the same. But besides all these things, clothe yourselves with love, for it is a perfect bond of union.

question: What does Paul mean by "the secret of God, namely, Christ, in whom are carefully hidden all the treasures of wisdom and of knowledge"?

options.text: That true wisdom is only accessible through secret rituals and mystical experiences.

That the full and true knowledge of God and his purposes is not found in human philosophies or law writings, but exclusively in the person and work of Jesus Christ, who reveals the formerly hidden secret of God.
That the Old Testament scriptures have become worthless and only Christ counts.
That Christ will remain a mystery until he returns.

explanation: Unlike the deceptive philosophies circulating in Colossians, in Christ are found all the true treasures of understanding God and his plans, the revealed "sacred secret" of God.
verseTextContent: This is so that their hearts may be comforted and that they may be harmoniously joined together in love and may have all the riches that result from the full assurance of their understanding, in order to gain an accurate knowledge of the sacred secret of God, namely, Christ. Carefully concealed in him are all the treasures of wisdom and of knowledge.

question: At Colossians 1:24, Paul speaks of his rejoicing in his sufferings for the Colossians and of "following in his flesh what is lacking in regard to the sufferings of the Christ for his body, which is the congregation".

options.text: That Christ's sufferings were incomplete and that Paul must complete them.

That Paul, as an apostle, shared in the sufferings that Christ endured for his church (his body) and that his followers must also experience to some extent as they continue the work of Christ, fills the "measure" of the sufferings predestined for the congregation.
That Paul suffered more than Christ himself suffered.
That Paul's sufferings have a grieving effect on the sins of the Colossians.

explanation: For the sacrifice of Christ was perfect and unique. Paul does not mean that he adds anything to the work of Christ's redemption, but rather, as a servant of Christ and in service to the church (the body of Christ), he suffers the tribulations associated with preaching the gospel in a hostile world. He sees his sufferings as a continuation and part of the sufferings that Christ and his followers must endure for the sake of the gospel until the full measure of tribulations for the church is reached.
verseTextContent: I am now rejoicing in my sufferings for your sake, and I am undergoing the tribulations of the Christ that are yet lacking in my flesh in behalf of his body, which is the congregation.

question: What three main Christian qualities does Paul commend to the Thessalonians at the outset of his letter? (1 Thessalonians 1:3)

options.text: Their wisdom, their wealth, their power.
Their faith, their love, and their endurance, because of their hope in our Lord Jesus Christ.
Their hospitality, their generosity and their joy.
Their eloquence, their knowledge, and their prophetic gifts.

explanation: Paul thankfully remembers the Thessalonians, highlighting their living faith as shown by works, their self-sacrificing love, and their enduring endurance as borne by the hope of the return of Jesus Christ.
verseTextContent: We always thank God when we mention all of you in our prayers, for we continually remember your faithful work, your loving labor, and your endurance because of your hope in our Lord Jesus Christ in the presence of our God and Father.

question: What admonition does Paul give the Thessalonians at 1 Thessalonians 5:17, which they should "continue to do"?

options.text: Studying the Scriptures.
Praying for you.
Do good deeds.
Preach the gospel.

explanation: In a series of brief, concise exhortations at the end of the letter, Paul urges believers to "pray incessantly", which means an attitude of constant association and dependence on God.
verseTextContent: Pray constantly.

question: What comfort does Paul give the Thessalonians regarding believers who are "asleep in death" in view of Christ's return? (1 Thessalonians 4:13-14)

options.text: That they will immediately go to heaven as angels.
That Jesus will awaken the sleeping ones when he returns and take them with him so that they are not at a disadvantage to the living.
That their souls are in a state of intermittent waiting for judgment.
That they're already in heaven praying for the living.

explanation: Paul wanted to comfort the Thessalonians who were mourning the loss of their fellow believers, assuring them that those who had fallen asleep in Christ would be resurrected at his coming and taken away with the rest of the faithful who were then alive.
verseTextContent: Moreover, brothers, we do not want you to be ignorant about those who are sleeping in death, so that you may not sorrow as the rest do who have no hope. For if we have faith that Jesus died and rose again, so too God will bring with him those who have fallen asleep in death through Jesus.

question: How will the "day of Jehovah" (or "the Lord's day") come, as stated at 1 Thessalonians 5:2?

options.text: With many clear signs that anyone can recognize.
Just like a thief in the night, unexpected.
Slowly and gradually over many years.
Only for those who are not vigilant.

explanation: Paul emphasizes that Jehovah's day - the time of his intervention and judgment - will come suddenly and unexpectedly, just as a thief comes in the night.
verseTextContent: For you yourselves know very well that Jehovah’s day is coming exactly as a thief in the night.

question: At 1 Thessalonians 2:13, Paul constantly thanked God for a certain response of the Thessalonians to his preaching.

options.text: They admired his eloquence and wisdom.
They accepted the word of God, which they heard from him, not as the word of men, but as it is indeed, the word of God, which also works in them who believe.
They gave generously for his needs.
They immediately established many new house communities.

explanation: Paul was especially grateful that the Thessalonians recognized and accepted his message, not as mere human speech, but as God's own Word, and that it became effective and fruitful in their lives.
verseTextContent: Indeed, that is why we also thank God unceasingly, because when you received God’s word, which you heard from us, you accepted it not as the word of men but, just as it truthfully is, as the word of God, which is also at work in you believers.

question: What will happen to the living believers and resurrected sleeping believers at the Lord's return?

options.text: They are taken directly to the third heaven to live there forever.
together they will be caught up in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air, and so they will be with the Lord forever.
They will remain on earth and build an earthly paradise.
Only the 144,000 will be taken away, the rest remaining on earth.

explanation: Paul describes that the dead in Christ will be raised first, and then those who are still alive will be caught up together with them in clouds to meet the Lord in the air.
verseTextContent: because the Lord himself will descend from heaven with a commanding call, with an archangel’s voice and with God’s trumpet, and those who are dead in union with Christ will rise first. Afterward we the living who are surviving will, together with them, be caught away in clouds to meet the Lord in the air; and thus we will always be with the Lord.

question: What was Paul's main concern when writing the second letter to the Thessalonians, as shown in chapter 2?

options.text: The Thessalonians had stopped praying.
Some were disturbed by false messages and believed that Jehovah's day (or Lord's day) had already arrived or was imminent, leading to disorder.
They had not given Paul financial support.
The congregation was divided over differing doctrines.

explanation: Paul wrote this letter to reassure the Thessalonians who had been aroused by letters or oral statements that falsely seemed to come from him and thought that Jehovah's day was already here, leading to unemployment and disorder in some.
verseTextContent: However, brothers, concerning the presence of our Lord Jesus Christ and our being gathered together to him, we ask you not to be quickly shaken from your reason nor to be alarmed either by an inspired statement or by a spoken message or by a letter appearing to be from us, to the effect that the day of Jehovah is here.

question: What principle about work and food does Paul set forth at 2 Thessalonians 3:10?

options.text: That all believers should be provided for by the congregation.
'If anyone does not want to work, let him not eat.'
That work is only necessary for non-Christians.
That you only have to work as much as you need to survive.

explanation: Paul rebukes those in the congregation who are disorderly and do not work, perhaps because they are waiting for the Lord's early coming. He reminds them of the principle he had taught them: If anyone does not want to work, he is not entitled to eat.
verseTextContent: In fact, when we were with you, we used to give you this order: “If anyone does not want to work, neither let him eat.”

question: According to 2 Thessalonians chapter 2, what must happen before Jehovah's day comes?

options.text: The complete conversion of all Jews.
First, the apostasy must come and the man of lawlessness, the son of destruction, be revealed.
A world peace must be established.
All the prophecies of the Old Testament must be fulfilled in detail.

explanation: Paul corrects the false expectation of the imminent coming of Jehovah's day by pointing out that this event must be preceded by a great apostasy from the true faith and the appearance of a figure called "the man of lawlessness".
verseTextContent: Let no one lead you astray in any way, because it will not come unless the apostasy comes first and the man of lawlessness gets revealed, the son of destruction.

question: What admonition does Paul give to the brothers at 2 Thessalonians 3:13, even if some are walking in disorderly ways?

options.text: To expel these disorderly brothers from the congregation immediately.
Don't give up on doing good.
To withdraw from all worldly work.
To face them with severity and hardness.

explanation: Although Paul gives instructions on how to deal with disorderly brothers (to identify and restrict contact with them but to admonish them as brothers), he encourages fellow believers not to tire or give up on doing what is right and good.
verseTextContent: For your part, brothers, do not give up in doing good.

question: Who or what is "that which acts as a restraint" that Paul speaks of at 2 Thessalonians 2:6-7 and that still prevents the revelation of man of lawlessness?

options.text: The Roman government and its laws.
The exact identity is disputed, but it refers to a force or person who was still actively preventing the full unfolding of lawlessness in Paul's day.
The Holy Spirit, who is at work in the congregation.
The preaching of the apostles.

explanation: This is one of the most discussed passages in the New Testament. Paul says that the Thessalonians knew what seemed to be "abstinence" in his day. There was something or someone who delayed the full revelation of the "man of lawlessness".
verseTextContent: And now you know what is acting as a restraint, so that he will be revealed in his own due time. True, the mystery of this lawlessness is already at work, but only until the one who is right now acting as a restraint is out of the way.

question: What fate awaits the "man of lawlessness" at the revelation of the Lord Jesus, as described at 2 Thessalonians 2:8?

options.text: He will repent and be forgiven.
The Lord Jesus will destroy him by the spirit of his mouth and lift him up by the revelation of his presence.
He'll be bound for 1,000 years.
He will rule over the whole earth before Christ comes.

explanation: Paul prophesied that when "the man of lawlessness" is fully revealed, he will be destroyed at the mighty appearing of the Lord Jesus Christ, who will eliminate him by the power of his word (the spirit of his mouth).
verseTextContent: Then, indeed, the lawless one will be revealed, whom the Lord Jesus will do away with by the spirit of his mouth and bring to nothing by the manifestation of his presence.

question: To whom does Paul address this letter, which he calls his "true child in the faith"?

options.text: Titus
Timothy
The name of the person
Luke

explanation: Paul wrote this personal and at the same time official letter to Timothy, his young fellow worker and spiritual son, to support and guide him in his responsible assignment in the congregation in Ephesus.
verseTextContent: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the command of God our Savior and of Christ Jesus, our hope, to Timothy, a genuine child in the faith: May you have undeserved kindness and mercy and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.

question: What is "a root of all sorts of hurtful things", as Paul says at 1 Timothy 6:10?

options.text: Lack of education.
The love of money.
The desire for power.
The pursuit of pleasure.

explanation: Paul warns Timothy about the danger of the love of money, which can lead people away from the faith and cause them much pain.
verseTextContent: For the love of money is a root of all sorts of injurious things, and by reaching out for this love some have been led astray from the faith and have stabbed themselves all over with many pains.

question: At 1 Timothy 2:1-2, what instruction does Paul give regarding prayers for all sorts of people, including kings and rulers?

options.text: That you should pray only for your brothers.
Prayers, supplications, and thanksgiving are to be offered for all kinds of people, including kings and those in high positions, so that we may live quiet and quiet lives in all piety and sincerity.
That prayer should be done against unjust rulers.
That prayers for rulers should be offered only by the apostles.

explanation: Paul teaches that Christians should pray for all people, including those in positions of authority, so that believers may lead a peaceful life of godly devotion and that God's will be done for all people to be saved.
verseTextContent: First of all, then, I urge that supplications, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgiving be made concerning all sorts of men, concerning kings and all those who are in high positions, so that we may go on leading a calm and quiet life with complete godly devotion and seriousness. This is fine and acceptable in the sight of our Savior, God, whose will is that all sorts of people should be saved and come to an accurate knowledge of truth.

question: What qualities does Paul include for an overseer (an elder) in the congregation, as described in 1 Timothy chapter 3?

options.text: He must be rich and speak many languages.

He must be blameless, a husband of one wife, moderate in habits, sound in mind, tidy, hospitable, able to teach, not a drunkard, not a quarrelsome but reasonable, not a money lover, a man who is well-adjusted to his own household.
He must be young and dynamic and have a theological education.
He must be ready to take political office.

explanation: Paul lists a number of moral, character, and family requirements for men to serve as overseers (or elders) in the Christian congregation, emphasizing an exemplary way of life and the ability to teach and direct others.
verseTextContent: The overseer should therefore be irreprehensible, a husband of one wife, moderate in habits, sound in mind, orderly, hospitable, qualified to teach, not a drunkard, not violent, but reasonable, not quarrelsome, not a lover of money, a man presiding over his own household in a fine manner, having his children in subjection with all seriousness (for if any man does not know how to preside over his own household, how will he care for the congregation of God?), not a newly converted man, for fear that he might get puffed up with pride and fall into the judgment passed on the Devil. Moreover, he should also have a fine testimony from outsiders so that he does not fall into reproach and a snare of the Devil.

question: What is the "sacred secret of godly devotion" mentioned by Paul at 1 Timothy 3:16?

options.text: The exact method of getting rich.
The revelation of Jesus Christ: He was made manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, appeared to angels, was preached among the nations, believed in the world, received into glory.
The secret rituals and ceremonies of the early church.
The names of the angels who serve God.

explanation: Paul here summarizes in hymnical form the central aspects of the gospel and the person of Jesus Christ. These truths about Christ  his incarnation, his justification by the spirit, his appearance to angels, the worldwide proclamation of his message, faith in him, and his ascension  form the foundation and content of Christian godliness or godliness.
verseTextContent: Indeed, the sacred secret of this godly devotion is admittedly great: ‘He was made manifest in flesh, was declared righteous in spirit, appeared to angels, was preached about among nations, was believed upon in the world, was received up in glory.’

question: What counsel does Paul give to Timothy at 1 Timothy 4:12 regarding his youth?

options.text: He should wait until he is older before teaching or exercising authority.
Let no one look down on his youth, but let him be an example to the faithful in speech, in conduct, in love, in faith, in chastity.
He should only care for the young people in the congregation.
He should try to look older and more mature than he is.

explanation: Paul encouraged Timothy not to be intimidated or discouraged by his possibly young age, but to be a model in all respects - speech, conduct, love, faith, and chastity - and to be a model for other believers.
verseTextContent: Never let anyone look down on your youth. Instead, become an example to the faithful ones in speaking, in conduct, in love, in faith, in chasteness.

question: What important admonition regarding the word of truth does Paul give to Timothy at 2 Timothy 2:15?

options.text: It's only to study it in secret.
to do his utmost to present himself to God as a worker who has nothing to be ashamed of, who handles the word of truth properly.
It is only taught to those who have already believed.
To adapt it to the philosophical ideas of the time.

explanation: Paul urges Timothy to be a careful and conscientious person who understands and communicates God's Word correctly so that he can prove himself to be a faithful worker without any need to be ashamed of his assignment.
verseTextContent: Do your utmost to present yourself approved to God, a workman with nothing to be ashamed of, handling the word of the truth aright.

question: What does Paul say about the whole of Scripture at 2 Timothy 3:16-17?

options.text: That it's only useful for historical studies.
All Scripture is inspired of God and beneficial for teaching, reproving, setting things straight, training in righteousness, so that the man of God may be fully equipped for every good work.
That only parts of it are inspired by God.
That it is primarily used to predict future events.

explanation: Paul here emphasizes the divine inspiration and the extensive value of the entire Holy Scriptures, which serve as a vital source of teaching, correction, and guidance in righteous living to equip the servant of God for his ministry.
verseTextContent: All Scripture is inspired of God and beneficial for teaching, for reproving, for setting things straight, for disciplining in righteousness, so that the man of God may be fully competent, completely equipped for every good work.

question: At 2 Timothy 2:2, what counsel does Paul give Timothy regarding the passing on of the teachings he heard from Paul?

options.text: He should keep it to himself to avoid misunderstandings.
These things are trustworthy to people who will in turn be adequately qualified to teach others.
Just spread them in writing.
They are only taught to those who are already observers.

explanation: Timothy was to entrust what he had learned from Paul to trustworthy men who would then be able to pass on the truths to others and thus ensure the continuity of sound teaching.
verseTextContent: and the things you heard from me that were supported by many witnesses, these things entrust to faithful men, who, in turn, will be adequately qualified to teach others.

question: What difficult situation did Paul find himself in when he wrote his second letter to Timothy, as shown by the letter? (2 Timothy 1:8, 16; 4:6) What did Paul find himself in?

options.text: He was on a successful mission trip to Spain.
He was imprisoned in Rome, awaiting his impending death (martyrdom), and many had abandoned him.
He was the head of the congregation in Jerusalem.
He recovered from a serious illness in Ephesus.

explanation: The second letter to Timothy is marked by the fact that Paul was in his second Roman prison and was about to die a victim.
verseTextContent: For I am already being poured out like a drink offering, and the time for my releasing is imminent. I have fought the fine fight, I have run the race to the finish, I have observed the faith. From this time on, there is reserved for me the crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous judge, will give me as a reward in that day, yet not to me only, but also to all those who have loved his manifestation.

question: In 2 Timothy chapter 3, Paul warns Timothy of "critical times hard to deal with". What features of people in these "last days" does he mention, among other things?

options.text: They will be especially godly, loving, and generous.

They will be selfish, money-loving, conceited, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, without natural affection, unapologetic, slanderers, without self-control, cruel, without love of goodness, betrayers, unreasonable, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than God, who have a form of godly devotion but who prove false as to its power.
They will strive for peace and end wars.
They will gain great wisdom and will understand all the secrets of God.

explanation: Paul gives a dark picture of the characteristics that would prevail in "the last days", and this list of negative ones serves as a warning and an encouragement for Timothy to hold fast to sound doctrine and to turn away from such ones.
verseTextContent: But know this, that in the last days critical times hard to deal with will be here. For men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, boastful, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having an appearance of godliness but proving false to its power; and from these turn away.

question: What urgent commission regarding his preaching work does Paul give to Timothy at 2 Timothy 4:2?

options.text: He should wait until the pursuit ceases.
Preach the word, press on it in favorable times and in unfavorable times, correct in wisdom, exhort and exhort with all longsuffering and skill in teaching.
He should only focus on writing letters.
He should find a quieter place to work.

explanation: In view of the critical times ahead and the tendency of people to turn away from the truth, Paul urges Timothy to preach and teach the Word of God with urgency and perseverance, whether in favorable or unfavorable times, patiently correcting and exhorting.
verseTextContent: Preach the word; be at it urgently in favorable times and difficult times; reprove, reprimand, exhort, with all patience and art of teaching.

question: To whom is Paul writing this letter, and where did he leave it to correct certain matters in the congregations?

options.text: To Timothy at Ephesus.
To Titus on the island of Crete.
To Philemon in Colossae.
To the congregation in Rome.

explanation: Paul wrote this letter to his fellow worker Titus, whom he had left on Crete to correct deficiencies in the congregations and to appoint elders in the various cities.
verseTextContent: to Titus, a genuine child according to the faith we share: May you have undeserved kindness and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Savior. I left you in Crete so that you would correct the things that were defective and make appointments of elders in city after city, as I instructed you:

question: What should older women teach younger women, as found at Titus 2:3-5?

options.text: How to gain wealth and influence.

To love their husbands, to love their children, to be sound in mind, to be chaste, to be homemakers, to be kind, to be in subjection to their own husbands, so that the word of God may not be spoken of abusively.
To excel in the congregation as teachers.
The latest fashion trends and social patterns.

explanation: Paul gives instructions to various groups in the congregation that older women should lead by example in the fulfillment of their family and personal responsibilities in a godly way.
verseTextContent: Likewise, let the older women be reverent in behavior, not slanderous, not enslaved to a lot of wine, teachers of what is good, so that they may advise the younger women to love their husbands, to love their children, to be sound in mind, chaste, working at home, good, subjecting themselves to their own husbands, so that the word of God may not be spoken of abusively.

question: What qualities should an overseer (an elder) have, among other things, as described at Titus 1:7-9?

options.text: He must be eloquent and philosophically educated.

He must be free from accusation, not selfish, not angry, not a loud drinker, not a slayer, not a greedy person, but a welcoming person, a man of good will, sound in mind, fair, loyal, self - controlled, and a man who holds fast to the faithful word as to his teaching ability.
He must have been in the faith for many years and be of old age.
He must be single in order to devote himself fully to the ministry.

explanation: Like the first letter to Timothy, Paul here lists the high moral and spiritual requirements for men to serve as overseers in the congregation, including a faultless character, self-control, and the ability to hold fast to sound doctrine and to teach others.
verseTextContent: For as God’s steward, an overseer must be free from accusation, not self-willed, not quick-tempered, not a drunkard, not violent, not greedy of dishonest gain, but hospitable, a lover of goodness, sound in mind, righteous, loyal, self-controlled, holding firmly to the faithful word as respects his art of teaching, so that he may be able both to encourage by the teaching that is wholesome and to reprove those who contradict.

question: According to Titus 3:5, what is the basis for God's salvation of believers?

options.text: Because of their own works of righteousness.
not because of righteous deeds we had done, but because of his mercy, through the washing of regeneration and renewal by the Holy Spirit.
By strictly observing the ceremonial laws.
By their descent and their membership in the people of Israel.

explanation: Paul emphasizes that salvation is not based on human works or righteous works, but on the mercy of God, through the spiritual rebirth and renewal of the holy spirit.
verseTextContent: However, when the kindness of our Savior, God, and his love for mankind were manifested (not because of any righteous works we had done, but because of his own mercy), he saved us by means of the bath that brought us to life and by making us new by holy spirit.

question: At Titus 1:12, Paul quotes a negative judgment about the Cretans themselves ('Cretans are always liars, vicious wild beasts, idle devourers'). What was the purpose of this quote in his letter to Titus?

options.text: To condemn all the Cretans and to turn away from them.
To make this testimony true, and to correct those who are apostates and false teachers in the Cretan churches, so that they may be healed in the faith.
To show that the Cretans are un receptive to the gospel.
To advise Titus to leave Crete as soon as possible.

explanation: Paul quotes a Cretan prophet to emphasize the challenges Titus faced in Crete, and the negative characterization served to emphasize the need for Titus to correct the apostate members of the congregations, often influenced by Jewish teachings and useless controversies, with due rigor to bring them back to a sound faith.
verseTextContent: A certain one of them, their own prophet, said: “Creʹtans are always liars, injurious wild beasts, idle gluttons.” This witness is true. For this very reason, keep on reproving them with severity so that they may be healthy in the faith, paying no attention to Jewish fables and commandments of men who turn away from the truth.

question: According to Titus 3:1-2, what should Christians be prepared to do, and how should they treat all people, including governments and authorities?

options.text: To rebel against unjust governments and to fight for their rights.
to be subject and obedient to governments and authorities, to be ready for every good work, to speak ill of no one, to be non - contentious, but to be reasonable, showing all mildness to all men.
To isolate oneself from all worldly authorities and to maintain no contact.
To obey only those authorities who uphold Christian values.

explanation: Paul urged Titus to remind the people to be in subjection to the authorities and to obey them, to be ready to do good, not to speak ill of anyone, to be peaceable and reasonable, and to be gentle toward all men, so that everyone will be well-liked.
verseTextContent: Continue reminding them to be in subjection and to be obedient to governments and authorities, to be ready for every good work, to speak injuriously of no one, not to be quarrelsome, but to be reasonable, displaying all mildness toward all men.

question: To whom is Paul's letter primarily addressed, calling him "our beloved and fellow worker"?

options.text: Timothy
The name of the person
Onesimus
Titus

explanation: Paul addresses this personal letter to Philemon, a wealthy Christian in Colossae, whose home probably housed a congregation, and also mentions Appias (probably Philemon's wife) and Archippus (possibly her son).
verseTextContent: Paul, a prisoner for the sake of Christ Jesus, and Timothy our brother, to Phi·leʹmon our beloved fellow worker, and to Apʹphi·a our sister, and to Ar·chipʹpus our fellow soldier, and to the congregation that is in your house:

question: To whom does Paul refer as his "child" whom he "begotten while he was in his bondage"?

options.text: Tychicus
Onesimus
Mark
The Demas

explanation: The main reason for the letter is Onesimus, a runaway slave of Philemon who met Paul in prison and became a Christian.
verseTextContent: I am appealing to you for my child, whose father I became while in prison, O·nesʹi·mus.

question: What was the former relationship between Philemon and Onesimus, and how had Onesimus' conversion to Christianity changed that relationship, as Paul illustrates?

options.text: Onesimus was Philemon's business partner, but he had deceived him.
Onesimus was a runaway slave of Philemon, who was previously useless to him, but now as a Christian he has become a beloved and useful brother.
Onesimus was a free agent of Philemon, who had left him.
Onesimus was the son of Philemon, who had run away from home.

explanation: Onesimus was a slave who had escaped from his master Philemon and may have caused him harm ('formerly useless'). After being converted to Christianity by Paul, Paul now sees Onesimus not only as a slave but as a "beloved brother" and as someone who is now "useful" to both Philemon and Paul.
verseTextContent: He was formerly useless to you, but now he is useful to you and to me.

question: What request does Paul make to Philemon regarding the taking of Onesimus?

options.text: He was to punish Onesimus severely, but then accept him back as a slave.
He should receive Onesimus not only as a slave but as a beloved brother, as he would receive Paul himself, and forgive him any harm that may come to him.
He should release Onesimus and send him back to Paul to serve him.
He was to sell Onesimus and give the proceeds to the congregation.

explanation: Paul appeals to Philemon's Christian love and asks him to no longer treat Onesimus as an escaped slave but to welcome him as a beloved brother in Christ, as he would welcome Paul himself.
verseTextContent: no longer as a slave, but as more than a slave, as a brother who is beloved, especially so to me, but how much more so to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord. So if you consider me a friend, receive him kindly the same way you would me.

question: Although Paul as an apostle had the authority to command Philemon, on what basis did he appeal to him instead?

options.text: Because of his apostolic authority and office.
For love, and as an old man and now also a prisoner of Christ Jesus.
Because of fear of God's punishment if Philemon disobeyed.
Because of the laws of the Roman Empire regarding slaves.

explanation: Paul consciously chooses not to assert his apostolic authority to command Philemon but to appeal to him on the basis of Christian love, and he also mentions his old age and his imprisonment for Christ in order to win Philemon's heart to his request and encourage a willing, loving response.
verseTextContent: For this very reason, though I have great freeness of speech in connection with Christ to order you to do what is proper, I would rather appeal to you on the basis of love, seeing that I am Paul an older man, yes, now also a prisoner for the sake of Christ Jesus.

question: What underlying Christian principle is particularly evident in Paul's handling of the situation of Onesimus and Philemon, even though the issue of slavery is not directly condemned?

options.text: The need to maintain strict social hierarchies.
That faith in Christ and brotherly love overcome social differences (like master and slave) and lead to a new kind of relationship in which all are equal in Christ.
That slaves always have the right to escape their masters.
That Christian teaching should have no effect on social structures.

explanation: Although Paul does not directly address the institution of slavery in this letter, he revolutionizes the relationship between Philemon (Lord) and Onesimus (slave) through the Gospel, who are now brothers in Christ.
verseTextContent: no longer as a slave, but as more than a slave, as a brother who is beloved, especially so to me, but how much more so to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord.

question: What is the main theme of the Hebrew letter regarding Jesus Christ compared to the Old Testament system?

options.text: That Jesus was a great prophet, but subordinate to Moses.
The superiority of Jesus Christ and the new covenant over the angels, Moses, the Aaronic priesthood, and the sacrifices of the old covenant.
That the Mosaic Law continues to be binding on all Christians.
That the temple service in Jerusalem must be resumed.

explanation: The letter to the Hebrews makes a detailed argument that Jesus Christ is far superior to the Old Testament system in person and work (as the Son of God, High Priest in the manner of Melchizedek, Mediator of a better covenant and perfect sacrifice).
verseTextContent: Long ago God spoke to our forefathers by means of the prophets on many occasions and in many ways. Now at the end of these days he has spoken to us by means of a Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, and through whom he made the systems of things. He is the reflection of God’s glory and the exact representation of his very being, and he sustains all things by the word of his power.
