And after he had made a purification for our sins, he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high. So he has become better than the angels to the extent that he has inherited a name more excellent than theirs.

question: What is faith as defined at Hebrews 11:1?

options.text: A sense of confidence without proof.
The sure expectation of things hoped for, the obvious proof of realities, though not seen.
Blind obedience to religious authorities.
The knowledge of God's existence.

explanation: Hebrews 11:1 gives a classic definition of faith: Faith is not mere vague hope but a firm, well-founded expectation of what is hoped for, and a conviction of things not seen with the physical eyes, based on God's promises and nature.
verseTextContent: Faith is the assured expectation of what is hoped for, the evident demonstration of realities that are not seen.

question: Who is Melchizedek, and in what way is Jesus a high priest "according to the way of Melchizedek" and not according to the way of Aaron? (Hebrews chapters 5 and 7)

options.text: Melchizedek was an ancestor of Aaron and the founder of the Levitical priesthood.
Now Melchizedek was king of Salem and priest of the Most High God. He was not a descendant of the priesthood, but he was paid a tenth by Abraham.
Melchizedek was an angel who appeared to Abraham.
Melchizedek was another name for the prophet Elijah.

explanation: The writer of the Hebrew letter shows that Jesus' priesthood is like that of Melchizedek, a kingly priest who served without a recorded genealogy and who even Abraham honored. This represents Jesus' higher and eternal priesthood, as opposed to the Levitical priesthood, which was based on lineage and limited in time.
verseTextContent: For this Mel·chizʹe·dek, king of Saʹlem, priest of the Most High God, met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings and blessed him, and Abraham gave him a tenth of everything. First, his name is translated “King of Righteousness,” and then also king of Saʹlem, that is, “King of Peace.” In being fatherless, motherless, without genealogy, having neither a beginning of days nor an end of life, but being made like the Son of God, he remains a priest for all time.

question: What is the use of Christ's blood in the new covenant, as opposed to the blood of bulls and goats in the old covenant?

options.text: It's only for symbolic cleansing.

For Christ's blood, which was offered once for all in the Most Holy Place, brings eternal redemption and cleanses our conscience from dead works, so that we may render sacred service to the living God, which animal sacrifices could not do.
It is less effective than animal sacrifices because it was offered only once.
It serves to appease God's wrath, but not to cleanse the conscience.

explanation: The writer argues that the animal sacrifices of the old covenant were not able to remove sins and perfectly cleanse the conscience, but that Christ's one-off sacrifice, through his own blood, provided eternal redemption and cleansed the conscience of believers so that they could serve God acceptably.
verseTextContent: He entered into the holy place, not with the blood of goats and of young bulls, but with his own blood, once for all time, and obtained an everlasting deliverance for us. For if the blood of goats and of bulls and the ashes of a heifer sprinkled on those who have been defiled sanctifies for the cleansing of the flesh, how much more will the blood of the Christ, who through an everlasting spirit offered himself without blemish to God, cleanse our consciences from dead works so that we may render sacred service to the living God?

question: What is the "anchor of the soul, secure and firm", mentioned at Hebrews 6:19, that reaches into the inner, behind the curtain?

options.text: The keeping of the Mosaic Law.
The hope that is based on God's unchangeable promises and oath and that is anchored in the heavenly sanctuary in the presence of Jesus Christ.
Human wisdom and philosophy.
The traditions of the Fathers of the Church.

explanation: The hope of salvation and eternal life is not a vague one, but a firm one, based on God's faithful promises, confirmed by an oath. This hope symbolically reaches into the Most Holy Place, where Christ has entered as our High Priest and Ruler for us.
verseTextContent: in order that through two unchangeable things in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled to the refuge may have strong encouragement to take firm hold of the hope set before us. We have this hope as an anchor for the soul, both sure and firm, and it enters in within the curtain, where a forerunner has entered in our behalf, Jesus, who has become a high priest in the manner of Mel·chizʹe·dek forever.

question: Hebrews chapter 12 urges believers to look to Jesus, the "Main Agent and Perfecter of our faith". What motivation or motive did Jesus have for enduring the suffering on the torture stake?

options.text: The desire for fame and recognition from the people.
For the joy that was set before him, he endured a torture stake, despising shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.
To demonstrate his divine power over death.
To give an example of stoic passion.

explanation: The writer encourages Christians to endure in the record of faith by looking to Jesus, who, with the prospect of future joy - his exaltation, the salvation of mankind, and the glory of God - was moved to endure the extreme suffering and the shame of death on the torture stake.
verseTextContent: So, then, because we have such a great cloud of witnesses surrounding us, let us also throw off every weight and the sin that easily entangles us, and let us run with endurance the race that is set before us, as we look intently at the Chief Agent and Perfecter of our faith, Jesus. For the joy that was set before him he endured a torture stake, despising shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.

question: To whom does James write his letter, as mentioned at James 1:1?

options.text: To the apostles at Jerusalem.
To "the twelve tribes scattered about".
To the non-Jewish Christians in Asia Minor.
To his personal friend Gaius.

explanation: James, likely a half-brother of Jesus and a leading figure in the Jerusalem congregation, addressed his letter to Jewish Christians living outside Palestine in the diaspora.
verseTextContent: James, a slave of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the 12 tribes that are scattered about: Greetings!

question: What does James say about faith without works in chapter 2, verse 26?

options.text: That faith alone is sufficient for salvation.
That faith, if it has no works, is dead in itself.
That works are more important than faith.
That faith and works have nothing to do with each other.

explanation: James emphasizes that a real, living faith is inevitably expressed in corresponding acts or works.
verseTextContent: Indeed, just as the body without spirit is dead, so also faith without works is dead.

question: What admonition does James give believers at James 1:19 regarding listening, speaking, and being angry?

options.text: Be quick to speak, slow to listen, slow to anger.
Everyone should be quick to hear, slow to speak, and slow to anger.
Slow to hear, quick to speak, quick to anger.
Be quick to hear, quick to speak, but slow to anger.

explanation: James gives important practical advice for communication and dealing with one another: Be willing to listen, consider, and not be hasty to speak and to restrain anger, since human anger does not bring about God's justice.
verseTextContent: Know this, my beloved brothers: Everyone must be quick to listen, slow to speak, slow to anger,

question: In James chapter 3, James compares the tongue to several things to illustrate its power and difficulty in controlling it.

options.text: A small fire that can set a big forest on fire.
A steering wheel that steers large ships.
A sharp two-edged sword.
A tooth in the mouth of horses.

explanation: James uses impressive images to illustrate the enormous power of the little tongue: the saw that guides horses; the small rudder that guides large ships; and a small fire that can ignite a huge forest.
verseTextContent: If we put bridles in the mouths of horses to make them obey us, we guide also their whole body. Look also at ships: Although they are so big and are driven by strong winds, they are steered by a very small rudder wherever the man at the helm is inclined to go. So, too, the tongue is a small part of the body, and yet it makes great brags. See how small a fire it takes to set a great forest ablaze!

question: In chapter 2, James warns against partiality or favoritism in the congregation.

options.text: The preference of men over women in teaching positions.
When a rich man comes into the congregation in gold jewelry and fine clothes, and a poor man in dirty clothes, the rich man is given a place of honor, while the poor man is told to stand or sit down.
The preference of persons with special intellectual gifts over those without.
The preference of Jews over non-Jews.

explanation: James sharply criticizes the practice of preferring the rich in the congregation and neglecting the poor, pointing out that such partiality is contrary to the "royal law" of neighborly love and means that one has become "a judge who makes bad decisions".
verseTextContent: My brothers, you are not holding to the faith of our glorious Lord Jesus Christ while showing favoritism, are you? For if a man with gold rings on his fingers and in splendid clothing comes into your meeting, but a poor man in filthy clothing also enters, do you look with favor on the one wearing the splendid clothing and say, “You take this seat here in a fine place,” and do you say to the poor one, “You keep standing” or, “Take that seat there under my footstool”? If so, do you not have class distinctions among yourselves, and have you not become judges rendering wicked decisions?

question: Who is the author of the letter of Jude, as he presents himself in verse 1?

options.text: Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve apostles.
Judas, a slave of Jesus Christ, but brother of James.
The apostle John under the pseudonym Judas.
An unknown author named Judas.

explanation: The author identifies himself as "Judas, a slave of Jesus Christ, but a brother of James", who is most likely the well-known head of the Jerusalem congregation and half-brother of Jesus, which would make Judas also a half-brother of Jesus.
verseTextContent: Jude, a slave of Jesus Christ, but a brother of James, to the called ones who are loved by God the Father and preserved for Jesus Christ:

question: What strong admonition does Jude give to believers in verse 3, although he originally intended to write about their common salvation?

options.text: Spend more money for the poor.
To fight a hard fight for the faith that has been handed over to the saints once and for all.
To completely isolate oneself from the world.
To seek new prophecies and teachings.

explanation: Forced to change his original writing schedule by the intrusion of ungodly men and false teachers into the congregation, Judas now urges believers to take a vigorous stand and defend the once unchanging Christian faith.
verseTextContent: Beloved ones, although I was making every effort to write you about the salvation we hold in common, I found it necessary to write you to urge you to put up a hard fight for the faith that was once for all time delivered to the holy ones.

question: What examples from history does Jude use to illustrate God's judgment of ungodly and apostate people? (Verses 5-7, 11)

options.text: The tower of Babel and the confusion of language.
The Israelites who died in the wilderness because of unbelief; the angels who did not keep their original position; Sodom and Gomorrah; Cain; Balaam; Korah.
Pharaoh at the time of the exodus and the Ten Plagues.
The destruction of the temple by the Romans.

explanation: To underscore the seriousness of the apostasy and God's sure judgment, Jude recalls several historical examples: the punished unbelieving Israelites in the wilderness, the fallen angels, the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah, and the negative examples of Cain (brother murder), Balaam (greed), and Korah (rebellion).
verseTextContent: Although you are fully aware of all of this, I want to remind you that Jehovah, having saved a people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed those not showing faith. And the angels who did not keep their original position but forsook their own proper dwelling place, he has reserved with eternal bonds in dense darkness for the judgment of the great day. In the same manner, Sodʹom and Go·morʹrah and the cities around them also gave themselves over to gross sexual immorality and pursued unnatural fleshly desires; they are placed before us as a warning example by undergoing the judicial punishment of everlasting fire.

question: How does Jude describe the wicked ones who have infiltrated the congregations and are a danger? (Verses 4, 12-13, 16)

options.text: As zealous and pious believers.

As men who turn God's undeserved kindness into a letter of uncontrollable change, denying their Lord, are like hidden cliffs at love feasts, like waterless clouds, like barren trees, like wild sea waves, like delusional stars; murmuring, complaining, acting according to their own desires, whose mouth speaks exalting things while admiring personalities for their own benefit.
As silent observers who do no harm.
As philosophers who seek deeper truth.

explanation: Judas uses a series of powerful metaphors and descriptions to characterize the corrupt character and hypocritical conduct of these false teachers, who are morally corrupt, exploitative, proud, and pose a serious threat to the faith and unity of the congregation.
verseTextContent: My reason is that certain men have slipped in among you who were long ago appointed to this judgment by the Scriptures; they are ungodly men who turn the undeserved kindness of our God into an excuse for brazen conduct and who prove false to our only owner and Lord, Jesus Christ.

question: What is the content of this unbiblical (but apparently well-known) prophecy?

options.text: The creation of a new heaven and a new earth.

That Jehovah has come with his holy myriads to execute judgment on all and to convict all the ungodly of all their ungodly deeds and of all the abominable things that ungodly sinners have spoken against him.
The birth of the Messiah from the line of David.
The destruction of the temple in Jerusalem.

explanation: Jude refers to a prophecy attributed to Enoch, the seventh from Adam (known from the apocryphal book of Enoch, but here quoted under inspiration from Judas), which announces the coming of Jehovah with a vast angelic army to execute judgment on all ungodly people and to condemn them for their wicked deeds and words.
verseTextContent: Yes, the seventh one in line from Adam, Eʹnoch, also prophesied about them when he said: “Look! Jehovah came with his holy myriads to execute judgment against all, and to convict all the ungodly concerning all their ungodly deeds that they did in an ungodly way, and concerning all the shocking things that ungodly sinners spoke against him.”

question: At the end of his letter (verses 20-23) what counsel does Jude give believers to keep themselves in the faith and to help others?

options.text: To separate himself from all doubters immediately and condemn them.

Build themselves on their most holy faith, pray with holy spirit, keep themselves in God's love while waiting for the mercy of Jesus Christ for everlasting life; and continue to show mercy to some who have doubts, tearing them out of the fire; but to others show mercy with fear, hating even the inner garment soiled by the flesh.
To establish new laws and rules to prevent misinformation.
Choosing a new leader to solve the problems.

explanation: Jude concludes with practical exhortations: Believers should strengthen themselves spiritually by building on their faith, praying in the spirit, and remaining in God's love, while at the same time seeking to save those who have been affected by false teachings or have doubts, with compassion and discernment, while avoiding any defilement by their sinful ways.
verseTextContent: But you, beloved ones, build yourselves up on your most holy faith, and pray with holy spirit, in order to keep yourselves in God’s love, while you await the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ with everlasting life in view. Also, continue showing mercy to some who have doubts; save them by snatching them out of the fire. But continue showing mercy to others, doing so with fear, while you hate even the garment that has been stained by the flesh.

question: What two main characters are at the center of the love story in the epic?

options.text: King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba.
A shepherd boy and a girl from the country (the Shulammite).
David and Bathsheba.
Adam and Eve.

explanation: The Book of Proverbs describes the deep and faithful love between a young woman from the village of Shulam (or Shunem), the Shulammite, and a shepherd boy.
verse: Song of Solomon 1:5-6; 6:13 (als Hinweis auf die Figuren)
verseTextContent: I am dark, but lovely, O daughters of Jerusalem,Like the tents of Keʹdar, like the tent cloths of Solʹo·mon. Do not stare at me because I am swarthy,Because the sun has gazed upon me. The sons of my mother were angry with me;They appointed me the keeper of the vineyards,But my own vineyard I did not keep.

question: What famous king is mentioned in the Song of Solomon who also promotes the affection of the Shulammite, but whose wealth and power cannot overcome her love for her shepherd?

options.text: King David
King Solomon
The Pharaoh of Egypt
King Hiram of Tyre

explanation: King Solomon, known for his wisdom and wealth, is one of the characters in the Song of Solomon. He is impressed by the beauty of the Shulammite and tries to win her over for his court, but her love belongs to a simple shepherd.
verseTextContent: The song of songs, which is Solʹo·mon’s:

question: What recurring request or appeal does the Shulammite make to the "daughters of Jerusalem" regarding love?

options.text: You're supposed to help her win the king for herself.
They should not try to arouse or arouse love in her until she likes it (or: until she awakens by herself).
They should sing their love song.
You're supposed to find your lover for her.

explanation: Several times in the Song of Solomon, the Shulammite urges the daughters of Jerusalem (probably the court ladies) not to arouse love artificially or prematurely, but to let it go on its natural course and wait until it awakens by itself.
verseTextContent: I put you under oath, O daughters of Jerusalem,By the gazelles and the does of the field: Do not try to awaken or arouse love in me until it feels inclined.

question: What quality of love is especially highlighted in Song of Solomon 8:6-7 when compared with death and Sheol?

options.text: Their fleetingness and transience.
Their strength and resilience ('Love is as strong as death'), their jealousy ('Hell is as stubborn as the pursuit of exclusive devotion') and their inability to be bought by wealth.
Her ability to heal all wounds.
Your connection to pain and suffering.

explanation: The Holy Quran describes true love as an unconquerable force, as strong and unyielding as death and the grave. Large amounts of water cannot erase it, and no wealth can buy it. It demands exclusive devotion.
verseTextContent: Place me as a seal upon your heart,As a seal upon your arm,For love is as strong as death is,And exclusive devotion is as unyielding as the Grave. Its flames are a blazing fire, the flame of Jah. Surging waters cannot extinguish love,Nor can rivers wash it away. If a man would offer all the wealth of his house for love,It would be utterly despised.”

question: The Sulamite often compares her beloved shepherd to animals and plants of nature (e.g., 'As an apple tree among the trees of the forest, so is my beloved among the sons').

options.text: That he's uncivilized and wild.
Its uniqueness, strength, beauty and the joy and protection it finds in it, as opposed to the artificial stimuli of the court.
That he's unreliable and unstable like nature.
That he's simple and uneducated.

explanation: By comparing the natural beauty and strength of an apple tree, a gazelle, or other elements of nature, the Sulamite expresses her deep admiration for her lover's natural, unadulterated qualities, which are outstanding, refreshing, and provide protection and joy, in stark contrast to the often artificial and lavish life in the royal court.
verseTextContent: “Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest,So is my dear one among the sons. I passionately desire to sit in his shade,And his fruit is sweet to my taste.

question: Although the Hohelied is a human love story, how is it often interpreted in the conventional or allegorical sense by Jews and Christians?

options.text: A warning of the dangers of romantic love.
Often by Jews as Jehovah's love for his people Israel; often by Christians as Christ's love for his congregation (the bride of Christ).
It's a purely historical record of Solomon's love affairs.
As a textbook on marriage counseling and sexual ethics.

explanation: In Judaism, it is often interpreted as an allegory of the love between Jehovah and Israel, and in Christianity it is often interpreted as a representation of the love between Christ and his congregation (the church or congregation called his bride), and the faithfulness, devotion, and longing described reflects spiritual principles.
verseTextContent: (This question relates to the history of interpretation and theology of the book, not to a specific verse. The Song of Songs itself does not provide an explicit allegorical interpretation, but the themes of exclusive love, fidelity, and union have led to such interpretations.)

question: What historical event is the main subject of mourning and lamentation in the book of Lamentations?

options.text: The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah.
The destruction of Jerusalem and Solomon's temple by the Babylonians in 607 B.C.E. (or 587/586 B.C.E. according to secular chronology).
The division of the kingdom of Israel after Solomon's death.
The defeat of Israel against the Philistines, the capture of the ark.

explanation: The book of Lamentations is a collection of five poems that express the deep sorrow, pain, and despair over the catastrophic destruction of Jerusalem and the first temple by the Babylonian army under Nebuchadnezzar.
verseTextContent: א [Aleph] 1 How she now sits all alone, the city that was full of people! How she has become like a widow, she who was populous among the nations! How she who was a princess among the provinces has been put to forced labor! ב [Beth] She weeps profusely during the night, and her tears cover her cheeks. Not one of all her lovers is there to comfort her. All her own companions have betrayed her; they have become her enemies. ג [Gimel]

question: Who is traditionally considered the author of the book of Lamentations, although his name is not explicitly mentioned in the book itself?

options.text: King David
The Prophet Jeremiah
The Prophet Isaiah
The Writer Ezra

explanation: Although the book is anonymous, it is generally attributed to the prophet Jeremiah because of its style, theme (Jeremiah witnessed and prophesied the destruction) and ancient Jewish and Christian tradition.
verseTextContent: (This question refers to traditional authorship. The Septuagint translation begins with the words: 'And it came to pass, after Israel had been taken captive and Jerusalem laid waste, that Jeremiah sat weeping and lamented with this lamentation over Jerusalem and said:')

question: What poetic structure do the first four of the five lamentations have?

options.text: They are all written in free verse without a fixed structure.
They are written in alphabetical acrostic form, with each verse or stanza beginning with a successive letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
They all follow a strict rhythm.
They are built as a dialogue between God and the people of Israel.

explanation: The first four mourning songs are artfully designed as acrostic. Chapters 1, 2 and 4 each have 22 verses, corresponding to the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet, each beginning with the next letter. Chapter 3 has 66 verses, each with three successive verses beginning with the same letter.
verseTextContent: (This question relates to the literary structure of the first four songs/chapter of the book.)

question: Despite the deep sorrow and grief, what glimmer of hope or confidence in God is expressed at Lamentations 3:22-24?

options.text: That God has completely forgotten his people.
That the deeds of Jehovah's loving-kindness are not finished, and his mercies are not ceased, but are new every morning, and that Jehovah is the share of the complaining one.
That Israel's enemies will soon be destroyed.
That the temple be rebuilt immediately.

explanation: In the midst of deep despair, the writer recalls Jehovah's endless loving-kindness (or mercy), recognizing that God's mercy is new every day and that Jehovah himself is the true share and hope of his people, even in their distress.
verseTextContent: It is because of Jehovah’s loyal love that we have not come to our finish,For his mercies never end. They are new each morning; your faithfulness is abundant. “Jehovah is my share,” I have said, “that is why I will show a waiting attitude for him.” ט [Teth]

question: The book of Lamentations often portrays Jerusalem as a mourning woman, a widow, or an abandoned daughter of Zion.

options.text: The city's military weakness.
The deep pain, humiliation, abandonment and suffering of the city and its inhabitants after the destruction and loss of their former glory and relationship with God.
The fertility and beauty of the city before its destruction.
The political insignificance of Jerusalem.

explanation: The depiction of Jerusalem as a mourning, despised, and abandoned woman intensely illustrates the emotional depth of the nation's loss and suffering, conveying the feeling of shame, loneliness, and destruction of what was once holy and honored, and the breaking of the covenant relationship with Jehovah as a result of sin.
verseTextContent: א [Aleph] 1 How she now sits all alone, the city that was full of people! How she has become like a widow, she who was populous among the nations! How she who was a princess among the provinces has been put to forced labor! ב [Beth] She weeps profusely during the night, and her tears cover her cheeks. Not one of all her lovers is there to comfort her. All her own companions have betrayed her; they have become her enemies. ג [Gimel]

question: Although the book of Lamentations is marked by mourning, what underlying theological knowledge or cause of Judas' suffering is repeatedly implied or directly mentioned?

options.text: The arbitrary cruelty of the Babylonian conquerors.
The sins of the people of Judah, their disobedience to God's commandments, and their apostasy from Jehovah, resulting in God's judgment.
The failure of the political leadership to make alliances with stronger nations.
An inevitable fate that will eventually befall all nations.

explanation: Despite the complaint about immense suffering, the writer (traditionally Jeremiah) acknowledges that the disaster was not accidental or accidental, but a direct result of the people of Judah's continued sins, idolatry, and disobedience to Jehovah and his covenant.
verseTextContent: Her adversaries are now her master; her enemies are carefree. For Jehovah has brought grief to her because of her many transgressions. Her children have gone into captivity before the adversary. ו [Waw]

question: Where was the prophet Ezekiel when he received his first visions of Jehovah and the celestial creatures (cherubians)?

options.text: In Jerusalem, in the temple.
In exile in Babylon, by the river Kebar, among the captives.
In Egypt, where he had fled.
On the mountain of Sinai.

explanation: Ezekiel, a priest, had already been taken into exile with a group of Jews to Babylon, where he received his calling vision at the Kebar River in the fifth year of King Jehoiakin's captivity.
verseTextContent: In the 30th year, on the fifth day of the fourth month, while I was among the exiled people by the river Cheʹbar, the heavens were opened and I began to see visions of God. On the fifth day of the month—that is, in the fifth year of the exile of King Je·hoiʹa·chin— the word of Jehovah came to Ezekiel son of Buʹzi the priest by the river Cheʹbar in the land of the Chal·deʹans. There the hand of Jehovah came upon him.

question: What recurring phrase or title is Ezekiel often used by God to emphasize his human nature as opposed to God's glory?

options.text: "My Beloved Prophet"
"Son of Man"
"Servant of the Most High"
"Watchers of Israel"

explanation: Throughout the book, God speaks of Ezekiel more than 90 times as "son of man" (Heb. ben adam), a title that highlights his mortal human nature, especially in contrast to the majestic visions and divine authority revealed to him.
verseTextContent: He then said to me: “Son of man, stand up on your feet that I may speak with you.”

question: What symbolic act did Ezekiel have to perform to illustrate the siege and destruction of Jerusalem, writing the city on a brick and lying for a long time on his left and then on his right?

options.text: He had to build a model of the temple from clay and destroy it.
He had to take a brick, mount Jerusalem on it, surround it, and then lay 390 days on his left side for Israel's passing and 40 days on his right side for Judah's passing.
He had to cut his hair and beard and distribute it in different ways.
He had to bear a yoke to show subjection to Babylon.

explanation: Jehovah told Ezekiel to depict a miniature enclosure of Jerusalem, drawing the city on a brick, building siege works on it, and then laying a number of days on each side, each day symbolizing a year of punishment for the sins of Israel and Judah.
verseTextContent: “And you, son of man, take a brick and put it in front of you. Engrave on it a city—Jerusalem. Lay siege to it, build a siege wall against it, raise up a siege rampart against it, set up camps against it, and surround it with battering rams. Take an iron griddle and place it as an iron wall between you and the city. Then set your face against it, and it will be under siege; you are to besiege it. This is a sign to the house of Israel. “Then you should lie on your left side and lay the guilt of the house of Israel on yourself. You will carry their guilt for the number of days that you lie on your side. And I will impose on you 390 days, corresponding to the years of their guilt, and you will carry the guilt of the house of Israel. And you must complete them. “Then for a second time you will lie down, on your right side, and you will carry the guilt of the house of Judah for 40 days. A day for a year, a day for a year, is what I have given you.

question: What did Ezekiel see in his famous vision in chapter 37, which symbolized the restoration and revival of Israel?

options.text: A new and magnificent temple.
A valley of dry bones that came together, covered with tendons and flesh, and brought back to life by the Spirit of God.
A stream that flowed out of the temple and brought healing water.
Four living creatures with different faces.

explanation: In this impressive vision, Ezekiel saw a valley of dried bones, which, at God's command, were joined together, covered with sinews, flesh, and skin, and the spirit of God came into them, making them come to life again as a great army, symbolizing Israel's spiritual and national restoration from exile and hopelessness.
verseTextContent: So he said to me: “Prophesy over these bones, and say to them, ‘You dry bones, hear the word of Jehovah: “‘This is what the Sovereign Lord Jehovah says to these bones: “I will cause breath to enter you, and you will come to life. I will put sinews and flesh on you, and I will cover you with skin and put breath in you, and you will come to life; and you will have to know that I am Jehovah.”’”

question: What proverbial expression that denied individual responsibility for sins is refuted by Jehovah through Ezekiel chapter 18?

options.text: "Time heals all wounds".
"Fathers shall eat bitter grapes, and the sons their teeth shall be dull".
"As the father, so the son".
"Fate is inevitable".

explanation: Jehovah corrected this wrong viewpoint by means of Ezekiel, emphasizing the principle of individual responsibility: "The soul that sins - it itself will die". Each one is held accountable for his own actions.
verseTextContent: And the word of Jehovah again came to me, saying: “What does this proverb that you quote in the land of Israel mean, ‘Fathers have eaten sour grapes, but the teeth of the sons are set on edge’? “‘As surely as I am alive,’ declares the Sovereign Lord Jehovah, ‘you will not continue to quote this saying in Israel. Look! All the souls—to me they belong. As the soul of the father so also the soul of the son—to me they belong. The soul who sins is the one who will die.

question: In Ezekiel's vision of the new temple (chapters 40-48), what special features of the new temple stream, and what effect does it have?

options.text: He's a raging stream that destroys everything in its path.
It grows deeper and deeper, produces life (trees on its shores, fish in the Dead Sea, which it heals) and symbolizes Jehovah's blessing and provision for life through his pure worship.
It dries out in the summer and only drains water in the winter.
It was used primarily to irrigate the fields around Jerusalem.

explanation: The vision shows a stream of water flowing from under the temple's threshold to the Dead Sea, which is rising and deepening eastward, bringing life wherever it comes: the salt water of the Dead Sea is becoming healthy and rich in fish, and trees on its banks are growing that are constantly bearing fruit and whose leaves are healing, symbolizing the blessings and life-giving power that emanate from Jehovah's presence and his pure worship.
verseTextContent: Then he brought me back to the entrance of the temple, and there I saw water flowing eastward from under the threshold of the temple, for the front of the temple was facing east. The water was flowing down from under the right side of the temple, south of the altar.

question: At Jehovah's direction, what symbolic act did the prophet Hosea have to perform to illustrate Israel's (Ephraim's) unfaithfulness to God?

options.text: He had to put a yoke on his neck.
He had to marry a woman of prostitution (Gomer) and have children of prostitution.
He had to change his name.
He had to walk around barefoot and naked.

explanation: Jehovah instructed Hosea to marry a woman who would be unfaithful to him, a woman who was "a woman of fornication".
verseTextContent: When Jehovah started to speak his word through Ho·seʹa, Jehovah said to Ho·seʹa: “Go, marry a woman of prostitution and have children of prostitution, because by prostitution the land has turned completely away from following Jehovah.” So he went and married Goʹmer the daughter of Dib·laʹim, and she conceived and bore him a son.

question: According to Hosea 6:6, what is more important to Jehovah than sacrifices and burnt offerings?

options.text: To the exact observance of holidays.
To loving-kindness (Hebrew, chesed) and to the knowledge of God.
To the building of magnificent temples.
Fasting and public prayers.

explanation: Through Hosea, Jehovah emphasizes that to him inner qualities such as loving-kindness (loyal, enduring love) and a true, personal knowledge of himself are more important than purely outward religious rituals, such as slaughter and burnt offerings, when the heart is not present.
verseTextContent: For in loyal love I delight, not in sacrifice,And in the knowledge of God, rather than in whole burnt offerings.

question: What picture does Hosea use to describe the relationship between Jehovah and Israel that was broken by Israel's idolatry but was to be restored?

options.text: Like a king to his subjects.
Like that of a marriage  Jehovah as a loving husband and Israel as a (temporarily unfaithful but now accepted) wife.
Like a shepherd to his flock.
Like a potter's ear to his tone.

explanation: The whole book of Hosea is filled with the metaphor of marriage, representing the covenant relationship between Jehovah and Israel. Israel's apostasy from other gods is described as spiritual adultery.
verseTextContent: I will engage myself to you forever;And I will engage myself to you in righteousness and in justice,In loyal love and in mercy. I will engage myself to you in faithfulness,And you will certainly know Jehovah.’

question: What two nations often sought help from apostate Israel (Ephraim) and made covenants with them instead of relying on Jehovah, as Hosea criticized? (Eccl.

options.text: Moab and Ammon.
Egypt and Assyria.
Babylon and Persia.
Tyre and Sidon.

explanation: Hosea reproaches Israel (often called Ephraim) for seeking political alliances with the great powers of Egypt and Assyria in their distress and insecurity, instead of relying on Jehovah, their covenant God.
verseTextContent: Eʹphra·im is like a simpleminded dove, lacking good sense. They have called out to Egypt; they have gone to As·syrʹi·a.

question: Hosea 11:1 states: "When Israel was a boy, I loved him, and out of Egypt I called my son". To which two 'sons' does this statement refer prophetically and historically?

options.text: Only the prophet Hosea himself.
Historically, to the nation of Israel, which Jehovah freed from slavery in Egypt, and prophetically to Jesus Christ, who was also a child in Egypt and returned from there.
To the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh.
To King David and his son Solomon.

explanation: This verse primarily refers to the historical deliverance of the nation of Israel (called by God his 'son') from Egypt, but the Gospel of Matthew (2:15) quotes this verse and applies it to Jesus, whose family fled with him to Egypt to escape Herod and later returned to Israel.
verseTextContent: “When Israel was a boy, I loved him,And out of Egypt I called my son.

question: What punishment does Jehovah announce at Hosea 13:14, but does he also view it as a means of final deliverance?

options.text: An eternal banishment from the Promised Land.

Jehovah rhetorically asks: 'Where are your thorns, O death? Where is your destructive power, O Sheol?' pointing to a future victory over death and grave by means of a resurrection, even though Israel will be delivered to judgment (death/sheol) before.
The complete erasure of the name Israel.
An incurable disease that will infect the entire people.

explanation: Although Israel is given "death" and "Sheol" (symbolic of destruction and exile) for their sins, Jehovah, through Hosea, indicates that this is not the final word. The rhetorical questions about the "sticks of death" and the "destructive power of Sheol" point to Jehovah's power to overcome death itself, implying a later restoration and resurrection hope.
verseTextContent: From the power of the Grave I will redeem them;From death I will recover them. Where are your stings, O Death? Where is your destructiveness, O Grave? Compassion will be concealed from my eyes.

question: What natural disaster is the prophet Joel vividly describing in chapter 1, which is devastating the land of Judah and serves as a harbinger of an even greater judgment?

options.text: It was a big earthquake.
A devastating plague of locusts, followed by a drought.
A flood across the Jordan.
It's a volcanic eruption.

explanation: Joel describes an unprecedented locusts invasion in several waves that will destroy all vegetation and lead to a severe famine, a call to repentance and a foretaste of the coming "day of Jehovah".
verseTextContent: What was left by the devouring locust, the swarming locust has eaten;And what was left by the swarming locust, the unwinged locust has eaten;And what the unwinged locust has left, the voracious locust has eaten.

question: (Joel 2:12-13) What is Joel's call to do in view of the coming disaster and "the day of Jehovah"?

options.text: We're going to have to rearm the military.
To repent with all their heart, with fasting, weeping, and mourning; to tear their hearts and not their garments, and to return to Jehovah.
To flee to other countries.
To worship other gods for help.

explanation: Joel emphasizes that the response to God's judgment must be not only outward (ripping away the garments) but also a genuine, inner repentance of the heart.
verseTextContent: “Yet even now,” declares Jehovah, “return to me with all your hearts,With fasting and weeping and wailing. Rip apart your hearts, and not your garments,And return to Jehovah your God,For he is compassionate and merciful, slow to anger and abundant in loyal love,And he will reconsider the calamity.

question: What remarkable promise does Jehovah make through Joel chapter 2, verses 28-29 (chapter 3, verses 1-2 in some translations) regarding the outpouring of his spirit?

options.text: That only kings and prophets will receive his spirit.

He will pour out his Spirit on every sort of flesh, and their sons and daughters will prophesy, and their old men will dream dreams and their young men will see visions. On their male servants and their female servants he will pour out his Spirit in those days.
That his spirit is given only to the people of Israel.
That the outpouring of his spirit will lead to immediate world peace.

explanation: Joel prophesied a time when God would pour out his holy spirit not only on a select group but on people of all sorts - men and women, young and old, servants and free - leading to prophetic declarations, dreams, and visions.
verseTextContent: After that I will pour out my spirit on every sort of flesh,And your sons and your daughters will prophesy,Your old men will dream dreams,And your young men will see visions. And even on my male slaves and female slavesI will pour out my spirit in those days.

question: What will happen on "the great and fear-inspiring day of Jehovah", and according to Joel 2:32 (chapter 3, verse 5 in some translations), who will escape?

options.text: All humans are destroyed without distinction.
The sun will turn into darkness and the moon into blood before the day of Jehovah comes, and it must occur that everyone who calls on the name of Jehovah will escape safely.
Only the rich and powerful are saved.
The judgment will only affect the surrounding nations, but not Israel.

explanation: Joel describes cosmic signs that herald the great and fear-inspiring day of Jehovah, but in the midst of that judgment there is a promise of salvation: Everyone who calls upon the name of Jehovah in sincere faith and obedience will be delivered and escape.
verseTextContent: The sun will be turned into darkness and the moon into bloodBefore the coming of the great and awe-inspiring day of Jehovah. And everyone who calls on the name of Jehovah will be saved;For on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem there will be those who escape, just as Jehovah has said,The survivors whom Jehovah calls.”

question: In Joel chapter 3 (chapter 4 in some translations), what is happening there when Jehovah gathers the nations into the "deep plain of Jehoshaphat"?

options.text: A great peace council of all nations.
Jehovah will judge the nations for their dealings with his people Israel, judge them for their wickedness, and restore his people.
The nations are making an alliance to attack Israel together.
A sporting competition between nations.

explanation: The "Pale of Jehoshaphat" (meaning "Jehovah is Judge") is a symbolic place of judgment, where Jehovah announces that he will gather the nations and hold them accountable for their hostility and oppression toward his people Israel.
verseTextContent: “For look! in those days and in that time,When I bring back the captives of Judah and Jerusalem, I will also gather together all the nationsAnd bring them down to the Valley of Je·hoshʹa·phat. I will enter into judgment with them thereIn behalf of my people and my inheritance Israel,For they scattered them among the nations,And they divided up my land among themselves.

question: What agricultural tools are to be turned into weapons, as stated at Joel 3:10 (chapter 4, verse 10) as a call to end-time warfare?

options.text: Sickle for spear, and sense for sword.
Plowshares for swords, and winemaking knives for lances.
Hammer for columns and axes for arrows.
Shovels to shields and hacks to arrowheads.

explanation: In contrast with the peace prophecy (e.g., Isaiah 2:4), where swords are turned into plowshares, Joel here calls on the nations to arm themselves for war against Jehovah and his people.
verseTextContent: Beat your plowshares into swords and your pruning shears into spears. Let the weak one say: “I am powerful.”

question: What was Amos' occupation before he was called by Jehovah to be a prophet, as he himself says at Amos 7:14-15?

options.text: He was a priest in the temple.
He was a shepherd and a carpenter of mulberry figs.
He was a royal court clerk.
He was a carpenter.

explanation: Amos was not from a prophetic family or school, but a simple man from Tekoa in Judah who earned his living as a shepherd and by picking mulberry figs (to make them ripe faster) before Jehovah called him to prophesy against the northern kingdom of Israel.
verseTextContent: Then Aʹmos answered Am·a·ziʹah: “I was not a prophet nor the son of a prophet; but I was a herdsman, and I took care of sycamore fig trees. But Jehovah took me away from following the flock, and Jehovah said to me, ‘Go, prophesy to my people Israel.’

question: Although Amos was from the southern kingdom of Judah, which of the two kingdoms of Israel was the target of most prophecies?

options.text: Against the southern kingdom of Judah.
Against the northern kingdom of Israel (often called Ephraim or Samaria).
To both empires equally.
Only against the surrounding pagan nations.

explanation: Although Amos also delivered judgmental words against Judah and the neighboring nations, his main focus and strongest criticism was on the northern kingdom of Israel, whose capital was Samaria, where he especially denounced idolatry, social injustice, and the luxurious lifestyle of the upper class.
verseTextContent: The words of Aʹmos, who was among the sheep raisers from Te·koʹa, which he received in vision concerning Israel in the days of King Uz·ziʹah of Judah and in the days of Jer·o·boʹam son of Joʹash, the king of Israel, two years before the earthquake.

question: What specific sins of northern Israel does Amos particularly condemn? (E.g., Amos 2:6-7, 4:1, 5:11-12)

options.text: The neglect of the temple in Jerusalem.
The oppression and exploitation of the poor and the needy, bribery in court, luxurious and selfish lifestyles, idolatry and sexual immorality.
Lack of military zeal and cowardice in the face of the enemy.
Too strict to observe the Sabbath law.

explanation: Amos sharply criticized the social injustice in the Northern Kingdom: the rich selling the poor for low debt, the right-wing, the oppressed, and the luxurious, which went hand in hand with idolatry and moral depravity.
verseTextContent: This is what Jehovah says,‘For three revolts of Israel, and for four, I will not reverse it,Because they sell the righteous for silver,And the poor for a pair of sandals. They trample the heads of the lowly into the dust of the earth,And they block the path of the meek. A man and his father have relations with the same girl,Profaning my holy name.

question: How did the Bethel priest Amaziah react to Amos' prophecies, and what counsel did he give Amos?

options.text: He repented and called the people to repentance.
He accused Amos of plotting against King Jeroboam and urged him to return to Judah and prophesy there, but not to Bethel, the royal sanctuary.
He asked Amos to pray for him and the king.
He recognized Amos as a true prophet and supported him.

explanation: Amaziah, the priest of the calf cult established by Jeroboam I at Bethel, saw in Amos' judgment messages a threat to the state and his own position.
verseTextContent: Am·a·ziʹah the priest of Bethʹel sent this message to King Jer·o·boʹam of Israel: “Aʹmos is conspiring against you right in the midst of the house of Israel. The land cannot put up with all his words. For this is what Aʹmos says, ‘Jer·o·boʹam will die by the sword, and Israel will surely go into exile from its land.’” Am·a·ziʹah then said to Aʹmos: “O visionary, go, run away to the land of Judah, earn your bread there, and there you may prophesy. But you must no longer prophesy at Bethʹel, for it is the sanctuary of a king and the house of a kingdom.”

question: At Amos chapter 5, Jehovah says: "I have hated your festivals, I have rejected them. Your burnt offerings and your grain offerings I have not approved of".

options.text: Because the sacrifices were not precious enough.
Because their worship was hypocritical and not accompanied by justice and justice in daily life; they neglected the poor and practiced social injustice.
Because they were singing the wrong songs.
Because the priests were not properly employed.

explanation: Jehovah made it clear that he hated outward forms of worship, such as festivals and sacrifices, when they were not accompanied by a just and merciful course in daily life.
verseTextContent: I hate, I despise your festivals,And I take no pleasure in the aroma of your solemn assemblies. Even if you offer me whole burnt offerings and gift offerings,I will find no pleasure in them;And I will not look with favor on your communion sacrifices of fattened animals. Spare me the din of your songs;And let me not hear the melodies of your stringed instruments. Let justice flow down like waters,And righteousness like an ever-flowing stream.

question: (Amos 9:11-15) Despite previous judgments, what hope of restoration does Amos give at the end of his book?

options.text: That Israel will defeat all the surrounding nations militarily.
The restoration of the 'fallen tent of David,' the return of the people from captivity, the abundant harvests and lasting possession of the land that Jehovah is giving them.
The immediate appearance of the Messiah.
That all the Israelites become priests.

explanation: Although Amos preached judgment primarily, he concludes his book with a hopeful vision of Jehovah's promise to restore the 'fallen tabernacle of David' - the Davidic kingdom and true worship - to bring his people back from captivity and to bless the land with fruitfulness and lasting peace, indicating a Messianic restoration.
verseTextContent: ‘In that day I will raise up the booth of David that is fallen,I will repair the breaches,And I will restore its ruins;I will rebuild it as in the days of long ago,

question: Against which nation is the prophecy of the book of Obadiah primarily directed?

options.text: Babylon
Edom (descended from Esau)
Egypt
Assyrian

explanation: The entire book of Obadiah is a judgment prophecy against Edom, the neighboring nation of Judah to the southeast, descended from Esau, Jacob's brother.
verseTextContent: The vision of O·ba·diʹah: This is what the Sovereign Lord Jehovah says regarding Eʹdom: “We have heard a report from Jehovah,An envoy has been sent among the nations: ‘Rise up, let us prepare for battle against her.’”

question: What sin is specifically condemned against Edom in Obadiah's prophecy for their sin against their "brother" Judah?

options.text: You did not support Judah militarily.
Their pride and violence toward their brother Jacob (Judah) by rejoicing in the misfortune of Judah, plundering it, and delivering refugees when Jerusalem was destroyed.
They tried to conquer the land of Judah.
They have introduced false gods into Judah.

explanation: Obadiah accuses Edom of extreme pride and hostility toward Judah, especially during the Babylonian destruction of Jerusalem.
verseTextContent: Because of the violence done to your brother Jacob,Shame will cover you,And you will perish forever. On the day when you stood off to the side,On the day when strangers took his army into captivity,When foreigners entered his gate and cast lots over Jerusalem,You acted like one of them.

question: (Obadiah 3-4) What did Edom's geographic position lead to?

options.text: To his strong allies in Egypt.
To his inaccessible position in the cliffs and hills ('Who will bring me down to the earth?').
To his great army and his wealth.
To a peace treaty with Babylon.

explanation: The Edomites lived in a mountainous, hard-to-reach region, giving them a feeling of deceptive security and superiority, thinking that no one could bring them down from their "horns of eagles" into the rocks.
verseTextContent: The presumptuousness of your heart has deceived you,You who reside in the retreats of the crag,Dwelling in the height, saying in your heart,‘Who will bring me down to the earth?’ Even if you make your dwelling high like the eagle,Or if you place your nest among the stars,I would bring you down from there,” declares Jehovah.

question: What principle of divine judgment is emphasized in Obadiah 15 regarding the treatment of Edom by Judah: "For the day of Jehovah is near against all the nations; as you have done, so it will be done to you; your course of action will return upon your own head"?

options.text: The principle of unconditional forgiveness.
The principle of retaliation or talion ('As you have done, so shall you be done').
The principle of universal salvation of all nations.
The principle of random divine intervention.

explanation: Obadiah announces that Edom will be punished according to its wickedness against Judah. The principle 'As you have done, so will it be done to you' (Lex Talionis, or Principle of Retribution) is applied here to Edom.
verseTextContent: For the day of Jehovah against all the nations is near. As you have done, so it will be done to you. The way you treated others will come back on your own head.

question: Although the book of Obadiah is primarily a judgment of Edom, what hopeful statement about the "house of Jacob" (Israel/Judah) and Mount Zion is found at the end of the prophecy?

options.text: That the house of Jacob will also be completely destroyed.

That they shall be taken captive on Mount Zion, and it shall be holy; and the house of Jacob shall take possession of its spoiled things; and deliverers shall come up into Mount Zion to judge the hill country of Esau; and the kingdom shall be Jehovah's.
That the house of Jacob shall make peace with Edom, and rule together.
That Mount Zion will be uninhabited forever.

explanation: In contrast with the destruction of Edom, Obadiah prophesies a restoration for Israel/Judah, with Mount Zion being a place of salvation and holiness, the house of Jacob regaining its inheritance, judging Edom, and finally the royal rule of Jehovah, indicating God's final sovereignty and the restoration of his people.
verseTextContent: But on Mount Zion will be those who escape,And it will be holy;And the house of Jacob will take possession of the things belonging to them.

question: The conflict between Jacob (Israel) and Esau (Edom) has a long history that dates back to their birth. What was a major reason for Edom's hostility toward Israel, as fulfilled in Obadiah's prophecy?

options.text: Disputes over water rights in the desert.

The seemingly deep-seated hostility and envy of Edom (the descendants of Esau) toward Israel (the descendants of Jacob), perhaps enhanced by Esau's loss of his birthright and blessing, expressed in harmful joy and aggression when Israel was in distress.
Different religious practices that led to conflict from the beginning.
A covenant of Edom with Egypt against Israel.

explanation: The enmity between the brotherly nations of Israel (Jacob) and Edom (Esau) is rooted in their history, perhaps because of Esau's loss of birthright and paternal blessing, which led to continued resentment.
verse: Obadiah 10, 12 (impliziert durch die Beschreibung der 'Gewalttat an deinem Bruder Jakob')
verseTextContent: Because of the violence done to your brother Jacob,Shame will cover you,And you will perish forever.

question: What assignment did the prophet Jonah receive from Jehovah, before which he first tried to flee?

options.text: Go to Egypt and warn Pharaoh.
to go to Nineveh, the capital of Assyria, and to preach against their wickedness.
To go to Babylon and comfort the Jews in exile.
To deliver a judgment message to the king of Israel.

explanation: Jehovah commissioned Jonah to go to the great and powerful city of Nineveh, the capital of hostile Assyria, to warn its inhabitants of their great wickedness before the coming judgment.
verseTextContent: The word of Jehovah came to Joʹnah the son of A·mitʹtai, saying: “Get up, go to Ninʹe·veh the great city, and proclaim judgment against her, for their wickedness has come to my attention.”

question: What happened to Jonah when he tried to flee his assignment and set sail for Tarsis?

options.text: The ship reached Tarsus safely, but Jonah became ill there.
A great storm came up, and the sailors threw Jonah into the sea at his suggestion, and he was swallowed up by a huge fish, in whose belly he was three days and three nights.
He was captured by pirates.
He changed his mind and immediately turned around.

explanation: When Jonah fled, Jehovah sent a powerful storm, and Jonah was thrown into the sea on his own initiative to save the ship and its crew.
verseTextContent: Then Jehovah hurled a strong wind at the sea, and there was such a violent storm on the sea that the ship was about to be wrecked.

question: How did the king and the inhabitants of Nineveh respond to Jonah's preaching that the city would be turned upside down in 40 days?

options.text: They mocked Jonah and chased him out of the city.
They believed in God, proclaimed a fast, put on a sackcloth (from the greatest to the least), and the king issued a penance decree, upon which Jehovah applied his punishment.
They ignored Jonah's warning and continued to celebrate.
They tried to kill Jonah.

explanation: Surprisingly, the Ninevites took Jonah's message seriously, showing sincere repentance, fasting, and putting on sackcloth - a sign of mourning and humility - and the king himself ordered a nationwide repentance.
verseTextContent: Then Joʹnah entered the city, and walking a day’s journey, he was proclaiming: “In just 40 days more, Ninʹe·veh will be overthrown.” And the men of Ninʹe·veh put faith in God, and they proclaimed a fast and put on sackcloth, from the greatest to the least of them.

question: How did Jonah react when Jehovah spared Nineveh, and what was his primary concern?

options.text: He rejoiced with the Ninevites and praised God for his mercy.
He was very angry and discouraged because his prophecy did not come and he was afraid that he would be a false prophet.
He asked Jehovah to send him to Nineveh as a permanent prophet.
He immediately returned to Israel and told the story of the miracle.

explanation: Jonah's reaction to God's mercy toward Nineveh was negative, angered because his prediction of destruction did not occur, showing that he had difficulty understanding and accepting God's extensive mercy, including Israel's enemies, and he was perhaps concerned about his own reputation as a prophet.
verseTextContent: But this was highly displeasing to Joʹnah, and he became hot with anger. So he prayed to Jehovah: “Ah, now, Jehovah, was this not my concern when I was in my own land? That is why I tried to flee to Tarʹshish in the first place; for I knew that you are a compassionate and merciful God, slow to anger and abundant in loyal love, one who feels grieved over calamity. Now, O Jehovah, please take away my life, for it is better for me to die than to live.”

question: What lesson about God's mercy and the value of human life did Jehovah try to teach Jonah by using the rapidly growing and then dried-up cucumber plant?

options.text: That plants are more valuable than humans.

If Jonah had felt sorry for a plant for which he had not worked, how much more should Jehovah have felt sorry for the great city of Nineveh, its many people (who did not know the difference between right and left) and its many domestic animals!
That you shouldn't cling to things that are fleeting.
That Jonah himself was responsible for the flowering and drying of the plant.

explanation: Jehovah used the rapidly growing and then rapidly dried-up rosewood to correct Jonah's wrong attitude. Jonah felt sorry for the shade-giving plant, but not for the 120,000-plus Ninevites.
verseTextContent: God asked Joʹnah: “Is it right for you to be so angry over the bottle-gourd plant?” At that he said: “I have a right to be angry, so angry that I want to die.” But Jehovah said: “You felt sorry for the bottle-gourd plant, which you did not work for, nor did you make it grow; it grew in one night and perished in one night. Should I not also feel sorry for Ninʹe·veh the great city, in which there are more than 120,000 men who do not even know right from wrong, as well as their many animals?” 1 Judgment against Samaria and Judah (1-16) Sins and revolt cause the problems (5) 2 Woe to the oppressors! (1-11) Israel regathered into unity (

question: In the New Testament, Jesus Christ referred to Jonah's experience in the belly of the great fish.

options.text: As an example of God's judgment on disobedient prophets.

As a "sign" (the sign of Jonah): Just as Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights, so the Son of man would be in the heart of the earth three days and three nights (a sign of his death and resurrection).
A warning against sea travel.
As proof of the existence of sea monuments.

explanation: Just as Jonah "resurrected" from the belly of a fish after three days and nights, so the Son of man (Jesus) would rise from the "heart of the earth" (the tomb) after three days and nights.
verseTextContent: In reply he said to them: “A wicked and adulterous generation keeps on seeking a sign, but no sign will be given it except the sign of Joʹnah the prophet. For just as Joʹnah was in the belly of the huge fish for three days and three nights, so the Son of man will be in the heart of the earth for three days and three nights. Men of Ninʹe·veh will rise up in the judgment with this generation and will condemn it, because they repented at what Joʹnah preached. But look! something more than Joʹnah is here.

question: Against which two capitals and kingdoms did Micah's prophecies focus primarily?

options.text: Babylon and Egypt.
Samaria (capital of Israel/Ephraim) and Jerusalem (capital of Judah).
Nineveh and Tyre.
Damascus and Edom.

explanation: Micah prophesied during the reigns of Judah's kings Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, and his messages included both the coming judgment of Samaria (the northern kingdom of Israel) and the future judgment and later restoration of Jerusalem (the southern kingdom of Judah).
verseTextContent: The word of Jehovah that came to Miʹcah of Moʹresh·eth, in the days of Joʹtham, Aʹhaz, and Hez·e·kiʹah, kings of Judah, and that he received in a vision concerning Sa·marʹi·a and Jerusalem:

question: According to Micah 6:8, what does Jehovah require of humans rather than many sacrifices?

options.text: The construction of magnificent temples.
To practice righteousness and to love kindness and to walk humbly with your God.
The exact observance of all ceremonial laws.
Fasting and praying daily.

explanation: This well-known verse summarizes God's basic expectations of his people: not just outward rituals, but above all a life characterized by justice in dealing with others, loving-kindness (loyalty, mercy) and humility in the relationship with God.
verseTextContent: He has told you, O man, what is good. And what is Jehovah requiring of you? Only to exercise justice, to cherish loyalty,And to walk in modesty with your God!

question: What famous prophecy about the birthplace of the future Ruler (Messiah) is found at Micah 5:2?

options.text: That he was born in Jerusalem.
And thou, Bethlehem Ephrata, too small to be among the thousands of Judah, out of thee shall come forth one unto me, who shall be ruler in Israel.
That he was born in Nazareth, in Galilee.
That he was born in Egypt and called from there.

explanation: Micah foretold that the Messiah, whose origins date back to ancient times, would come from the small, invisible city of Bethlehem Ephrata (to distinguish it from another Bethlehem) in Judah, and this prophecy was fulfilled at the birth of Jesus Christ.
verseTextContent: And you, O Bethʹle·hem Ephʹra·thah,The one too little to be among the thousands of Judah,From you will come out for me the one to be ruler in Israel,Whose origin is from ancient times, from the days of long ago.

question: In Micah chapter 4, verses 3-4, with what does Micah compare the state of peace that will come when the nations flock to Jehovah's mountain for instruction?

options.text: With an endless feast.

And they shall shew their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning-knives; and no nation shall lift up sword against nation, and they shall not learn war any more; but they shall sit every man under his vine and under his fig-tree.
With harmony in the animal kingdom, where predators live in peace with predators.
With a golden age when all people will be rich.

explanation: Micah paints a picture of a future world peace when nations turn to Jehovah's teaching: weapons of war will be turned into agricultural equipment, wars will cease, and everyone will live in security and prosperity under his own vine and fig tree.
verseTextContent: He will render judgment among many peoplesAnd set matters straight respecting mighty nations far away. They will beat their swords into plowsharesAnd their spears into pruning shears. Nation will not lift up sword against nation,Nor will they learn war anymore. They will sit, each one under his vine and under his fig tree,And no one will make them afraid,For the mouth of Jehovah of armies has spoken.

question: At Micah 7:18-19, the prophet praises God for a specific quality in dealing with sin and transgression.

options.text: His ability to punish sinners immediately and relentlessly.

His willingness to forgive transgressions, to overlook transgressions, and not to hold forever to his anger, because he is pleased with loving-kindness; he will throw their transgressions under his feet, and all their sins into the depths of the sea.
His exact record of all sins, to keep them for the day of judgment.
His power to eradicate sin through natural disasters.

explanation: At the end of his book, Micah praises Jehovah for his unparalleled willingness to forgive. God does not hold on to anger forever but finds favor in loving-kindness, forgiving sins completely and permanently, symbolized by the tossing of sins into the depths of the sea.
verseTextContent: Who is a God like you,Pardoning error and passing over the transgression of the remnant of his inheritance? He will not hold onto his anger forever,For he delights in loyal love. He will again show us mercy; he will conquer our errors. You will throw all their sins into the depths of the sea.

question: In chapter 3, Micah sharply criticizes the leaders, priests, and prophets of Judah. What was their chief error that caused Zion to be plowed like a field and Jerusalem to become a heap of rubble?

options.text: They were too yielding to the surrounding nations.
They twisted justice, hated good and loved bad, judged for bribe, taught for price, and prophesied for money, while falsely trusting in Jehovah.
They neglected the construction and maintenance of the temple.
They introduced new foreign gods into Judah.

explanation: Micah accuses the leaders of Judah  of both secular and religious  for their rampant corruption and injustice, corrupting the people, perverting the legal system, and abusing their spiritual offices for personal gain, all while hypocritically claiming that Jehovah is in their midst.
verseTextContent: Hear this, please, you heads of the house of JacobAnd you commanders of the house of Israel,Who detest justice and who make crooked all that is straight, Who build Zion with bloodshed and Jerusalem with unrighteousness. Her leaders judge for a bribe,Her priests instruct for a price,And her prophets practice divination for money. And yet they lean on Jehovah, saying: “Is not Jehovah with us? No calamity will come upon us.” So because of you,Zion will be plowed up as a field,Jerusalem will become heaps of ruins,And the mountain of the House will become like high places in a forest.

question: Against which mighty and cruel city, the capital of the Assyrian Empire, is the book of Nahum's prophecy primarily directed?

options.text: Babylon
Nineveh
Theben (no-ammon)
The Council

explanation: The entire book of Nahum is a proclamation of Jehovah's imminent and inevitable judgment of Nineveh, the capital of the Assyrian world empire known for its brutality and oppression.
verseTextContent: A pronouncement against Ninʹe·veh: The book of the vision of Naʹhum the Elʹkosh·ite:

question: How does Nahum describe Jehovah in chapter 1, verses 2-3, regarding his enemies and those who hope in him?

options.text: As a God who forgets and forgives quickly.
A jealous God, avenging his adversaries, slow to anger, great in power, and never without recompense; and a feast in the day of trouble, and a knower of them that seek refuge in him.
As an indifferent God who does not interfere in the world.
As one God who loves only his own people and hates everyone else.

explanation: Nahum portrays Jehovah as a God who, while exercising righteous wrath and vengeance against his enemies (such as Assyria/Nineveh), is slow to anger and provides protection and security for those who trust in him.
verseTextContent: Jehovah is a God who requires exclusive devotion and takes vengeance;Jehovah takes vengeance and is ready to express his wrath. Jehovah takes vengeance against his foes,And he stores up wrath for his enemies. Jehovah is slow to anger and great in power,But by no means will Jehovah hold back due punishment. His path is in destructive wind and storm,And the clouds are the dust of his feet.

question: What kind of warfare and destruction will Nineveh suffer according to Nahum's prophecies (e.g., Nahum chapters 2 and 3)?

options.text: A peaceful handover to a stronger empire.
A sudden and devastating military siege and conquest, with chariots, the races, the plunder, the fire and the end of their power.
A slow economic decline over many decades.
A destruction by a natural disaster like an earthquake.

explanation: Nahum describes the siege and fall of Nineveh in vivid pictures: the raiding chariots, the glowing of weapons, the roar of the attackers, the plundering of treasures, and the final devastation of the city.
verseTextContent: The shields of his mighty men are dyed red,His warriors are dressed in crimson. The iron fittings of his war chariots flash like fireIn the day he prepares for battle,And the juniper spears are brandished. The war chariots race madly through the streets. They rush up and down the public squares. They shine like burning torches and flash like lightning.

question: Why is Nineveh called "the city of bloodguilt" and "full of robbery", and why does God's judgment come upon it?

options.text: Because they sacrificed too many animals.
Because of their extreme cruelty, violence, oppression of other nations, idolatry, and military aggression that enriched them.
Because they refused to trade with other nations.
Because they did not receive Jehovah's prophets.

explanation: Assyrian and its capital city, Nineveh, were known for their ruthless wartime brutality, oppression of conquered nations, and insatiable plunder.
verseTextContent: Woe to the city of bloodshed! She is completely full of deception and robbery. She is never without prey!

question: (Nahum 3:8-10) What city is this?

options.text: Babylon
No-Amon (Thebes in Egypt)
The Council of Ministers
Tyrus

explanation: To show that even the strongest human fortresses cannot withstand God's judgment, Nahum recalls the case of No-Amon (the Egyptian Thebes). Thebes was a very powerful and well-fortified city, but was nevertheless conquered by the Assyrians (ironically Nineveh's own power).
verseTextContent: Are you better than No-aʹmon, which sat by the Nile canals? Waters surrounded her;Her wealth was the sea and her wall was the sea. E·thi·oʹpi·a was her source of boundless strength, also Egypt. Put and the Libʹy·ans were your helpers. But even she became an exile;She went into captivity. Her children also were dashed to pieces on every street corner. They cast lots over her honored men,And all her great men have been bound with fetters.

question: Although Nahum's message is primarily one of judgment against Nineveh, what positive effect did Nineveh's case have on Judah, as indicated at Nahum 1:15 (2:1 in some translations)?

options.text: Judah would become a world power immediately.

Behold, upon the mountains are the feet of him who brings good tidings, who proclaims peace. O Judah, celebrate your feasts, and pay your vows; for nothing will ever be used against you, but it will be destroyed.
Judah would take great riches from Nineveh.
All nations would submit to Judah.

explanation: The destruction of Nineveh and the end of the Assyrian threat meant a time of relief and peace for Judah, a "good news" that would allow Judah to return to its festivals and to fulfill its vows, as the threatening enemy ("nothing") would be eliminated.
verseTextContent: Look! On the mountains are the feet of one bringing good news,The one proclaiming peace. Celebrate your festivals, O Judah, pay your vows,For the worthless one will never pass through you again. He will be utterly destroyed.”

question: What is the shape of much of the book of Habakkuk, especially the first two chapters?

options.text: A collection of proverbs and wisdom teachings.
A dialogue or series of questions the prophet Habakkuk asked God and God's answers to them.
A historical account of the kings of Judah.
A series of songs of mourning over the destruction of Jerusalem.

explanation: The book of Habakkuk begins with the prophet expressing his confusion and questions about God's apparent inaction in the face of wickedness in Judah. God answers him, to which Habakkuk asks further questions.
verseTextContent: How long, O Jehovah, must I cry for help, but you do not hear? How long must I ask for help from violence, but you do not intervene? Why do you make me witness wrongdoing? And why do you tolerate oppression? Why are destruction and violence before me? And why do quarreling and conflict abound? So law is paralyzed,And justice is never carried out. For the wicked surround the righteous;That is why justice is perverted.

question: What nation does Jehovah announce to Habakkuk as his instrument in punishing apostate Judah, even though it is cruel and unjust?

options.text: Egypt
The Chaldeans (Babylonians)
Assyrian
Persian

explanation: In response to Habakkuk's first complaint about Judah's wickedness, Jehovah announces that he will raise up the Chaldeans (Babylonians)  a terrible and violent nation  to execute his judgment on Judah.
verseTextContent: “Look among the nations and pay attention! Stare in amazement and be astounded;For something will happen in your daysThat you will not believe even if it is told to you. For here I am raising up the Chal·deʹans,The ruthless and impetuous nation. They sweep through vast stretches of the earthTo seize homes not theirs.

question: What important statement about the righteous is found at Habakkuk 2:4, which is also quoted in the New Testament?

options.text: "The righteous one will possess many riches".
"But the righteous one will live by his faith".
'The righteous will never have to suffer.'
"The righteous will conquer his enemies".

explanation: Amid the Chaldean judgment announcements, Jehovah is revealing a basic truth: The righteous one will not live by his own strength or wisdom but by his faith (or faithfulness) in God and experience God's promises.
verseTextContent: Look at the one who is proud;He is not upright within himself. But the righteous one will live by his faithfulness.

question: Despite the coming destruction of the Chaldeans, what does Habakkuk decide to do at the end of his book (chapter 3)?

options.text: He decides to leave Judah and flee to Egypt.
He wants to rejoice in Jehovah and rejoice in the God of his salvation, even if all outward blessings (fig tree, vine, flocks, etc.) are left.
He plans to organize an armed resistance against the Chaldeans.
He falls into deep despair and gives up his faith.

explanation: Even when the worst disasters occur and all material blessings and basic necessities of life are lost, Habakkuk is determined to rejoice in Jehovah and to trust in his deliverance.
verseTextContent: Although the fig tree may not blossom,And there may be no fruit on the vines;Although the olive crop may fail,And the fields may produce no food;Although the flock may disappear from the pen,And there may be no cattle in the stalls; Yet, as for me, I will exult in Jehovah;I will be joyful in the God of my salvation. The Sovereign Lord Jehovah is my strength;He will make my feet like those of a deerAnd cause me to tread on high places.
