question: As Habakkuk struggles with the problem that God is using an ungodly nation (the Chaldeans) to punish his own sinful people (Judae), what assurance does Jehovah give him regarding the fate of the Chaldeans themselves?

options.text: That the Chaldeans will be forever unpunished because they are God's tools.
That the Chaldeans too would be judged and punished by Jehovah in due time for their own violence, pride, greed, and idolatry ('Woe to him that multiplies that which is not to be!').
That the Chaldeans would eventually repent and serve Jehovah.
That the Chaldeans would be defeated by an even more powerful nation without God intervening directly.

explanation: Although Jehovah uses the Chaldeans as his punitive instrument against Judah, this does not mean that their own wickedness and cruelty will go unpunished.
verseTextContent: Will not all of these speak a proverb, an allusion, and riddles against him? They will say: ‘Woe to him who accumulates what is not his—For how long?—And who makes even greater his own debt!

question: The third chapter of the book of Habakkuk is a lamentation prayer (or "shigjonoth"), in which what request or request does Habakkuk make to Jehovah after hearing of God's past acts of power?

options.text: That Jehovah may soften his judgment upon Judah.

Jehovah, I have heard the report of thee; I have been afraid, Jehovah, before thy works: in the midst of the years, O live it; in the midst of the years, thou wilt declare it; in the time of rebellion, thou wilt remember the loving-kindness.
That Jehovah may destroy the Chaldeans at once.
May Jehovah give him more visions and revelations.

explanation: After receiving God's answer that the Chaldeans would come, Habakkuk remembers Jehovah's mighty acts in the past (such as the exodus from Egypt), and in awe he asks Jehovah to revive and proclaim his work of salvation and judgment "in the midst of the years" (i.e., in the present time of distress), and to remember his mercy even when the upheaval (judgment) comes.
verseTextContent: O Jehovah, I have heard the report about you. I am in awe, O Jehovah, of your activity. In the midst of the years bring it to life! In the midst of the years make it known. May you remember to show mercy during the turmoil.

question: What central theme of the book of Zephaniah is described as a day of wrath, distress, distress, and darkness?

options.text: The establishment of a world empire of peace.
The great and fear-inspiring "day of Jehovah", a day of judgment upon Judah and the nations.
The joy of rich harvests and prosperity.
The celebration of a special anniversary.

explanation: Zephaniah's prophecy is strongly marked by the proclamation of "the day of Jehovah", a time of intense divine judgment that will come upon Judah for its sins and also upon the ungodly nations.
verseTextContent: The great day of Jehovah is near! It is near and it is approaching very quickly! The sound of the day of Jehovah is bitter. There a warrior cries out. That day is a day of fury,A day of distress and anguish,A day of storm and desolation,A day of darkness and gloom,A day of clouds and thick gloom,

question: What call does Zephaniah make on the "mild-tempered ones of the earth" at chapter 2, verse 3, before the day of Jehovah's anger comes?

options.text: Arming and resisting.
Seek Jehovah, all you meek ones of the earth, who have executed his own judicial decision; seek righteousness, seek meekness; you may be saved on the day of Jehovah's anger.
To flee to other countries.
To accumulate wealth to buy security.

explanation: In view of the judgment ahead, Zephaniah gives a hope to those who are humble and obey God's justice, urging them to continue seeking Jehovah, righteousness, and mildness, for that is what will save them on the Day of Judgment.
verseTextContent: Seek Jehovah, all you meek ones of the earth,Who observe his righteous decrees. Seek righteousness, seek meekness. Probably you will be concealed on the day of Jehovah’s anger.

question: What sins of Jerusalem (Judah) are denounced at Zephaniah 3:1-4 leading to Jehovah's judgment?

options.text: Lack of zeal in temple building.

Their rebellion, their reproach, their oppression; their princes are roaring lions, their judges are wolves, their prophets are arrogant and unfaithful, and their priests desecrate the holy place and do violence to the law.
Too close to Egypt.
The failure to convert the surrounding nations.

explanation: Zephaniah strongly condemns the corruption and moral decay in all sections of Jerusalem's society: the violent and unjust leaders, the selfish and false prophets, and the priests who disregard God's law and desecrate the holy.
verseTextContent: Woe to the rebellious, the polluted, the oppressive city! She has obeyed no voice; she has accepted no discipline. In Jehovah she has not trusted; she has not drawn near to her God. Her princes within her are roaring lions. Her judges are wolves in the night;They do not leave even a bone to gnaw until morning. Her prophets are insolent, treacherous men. Her priests defile what is holy;They do violence to the law.

question: What promise does Jehovah give to his cleansed remnant at Zephaniah 3:9 regarding their language and worship?

options.text: That they would all speak the original Hebrew language perfectly again.
That he would change the peoples into a pure language so that they would all call upon the name of Jehovah and serve him shoulder to shoulder.
That their prayers will always be answered, no matter what language.
That they will receive a new sacred scripture in a new language.

explanation: After the judgment and purification, Jehovah promises a change that will enable the nations (or the cleansed remnant) to call upon him in unity and purity and to serve him together.
verseTextContent: For then I will change the language of the peoples to a pure language,So that all of them may call on the name of Jehovah,To serve him shoulder to shoulder.’

question: At Zephaniah 1:12, Jehovah announces that he will search Jerusalem with lamps and search the men "who are dwelling in their own loins".

options.text: Men who are lazy and don't want to work.
Self-satisfied, indifferent, and apathetic people who have settled in their wealth or sin and believe that Jehovah will do no good or evil (i.e., will not intervene).
Men who drink too much wine and are drunk.
Men who secretly worship idols.

explanation: The image of the men "stabbed in their yeasts" refers to wine that is left standing for a long time on its soil (yeast) and becomes thick and sluggish, symbolizing people who have become spiritually sluggish and have become unreliable in their complacency and material prosperity and who no longer count on God's intervention.
verseTextContent: At that time I will carefully search Jerusalem with lamps,And I will call to account the complacent ones, who say in their heart,‘Jehovah will not do good, and he will not do bad.’

question: What hopeful future for the humble remnant of his people describes Zephaniah chapter 3, verses 12-13, after the judgment is executed?

options.text: They will rise to a powerful military nation.

Jehovah will leave a humble and small people, who will take refuge in the name of Jehovah; they will not do injustice nor speak lies, and they will graze and camp themselves, and there will be no one making them tremble.
They will all be prophets and priests.
They will inherit all the riches of the defeated nations.

explanation: After the cleansing by the Judgment, Jehovah promises to preserve a remnant of his people, marked by humility and trust in his name, who will live in righteousness, no longer practice falsehood, and will graze in security and peace under God's protection without fear of enemies.
verseTextContent: I will allow a humble and lowly people to remain in your midst,And they will take refuge in the name of Jehovah. Those remaining of Israel will practice no unrighteousness;They will not speak a lie, nor will a deceitful tongue be found in their mouths;They will feed and lie down, and no one will make them afraid.”

question: To which two Jewish leaders did the prophet Haggai primarily address his messages of encouragement to rebuild the temple?

options.text: To Ezra and Nehemiah.
To Zerubbabel the governor of Judah, and to Jeshua the high priest.
To King Darius (presumably Darius I) and his 10 highest officials.
to Zechariah and Malachi the prophets, and to Elijah the prophet,

explanation: Haggai delivered Jehovah's word to Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, the governor of Judah, and to Yeshua the son of Jehozadak, the high priest, who had the chief responsibility for leading the people and building the temple.

question: What was the main accusation or question that Jehovah addressed to the people through Haggai because they neglected to rebuild the temple?

verseTextContent: “All things, therefore, that you want men to do to you, you also must do to them. This, in fact, is what the Law and the Prophets mean.

question: Where was Jesus baptized, and by whom?

options.text: In the lake of Gennesaret by Peter.
In the Jordan from John the Baptist.
In the Mediterranean by one of his disciples.
In a well in Nazareth, Joseph.

explanation: Matthew reports that Jesus came from Galilee to the Jordan to be baptized by John the Baptizer, marking the beginning of his public ministry.
verseTextContent: Then Jesus came from Galʹi·lee to the Jordan to John, in order to be baptized by him.

question: What did Jesus say to the paralytic in Capernaum before healing him physically, which the scribes view as blasphemy?

options.text: Get up and go!
Child, your sins are forgiven.
Your faith has made you well.
Do you want to get well?

explanation: Jesus was teaching the man about forgiveness of sins, provoking the scribes to believe that only God can forgive sins.
verseTextContent: When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralytic: “Child, your sins are forgiven.”

question: Which of the following miracles of Jesus is first recorded in Mark's Gospel immediately after his baptism and temptation in the wilderness?

options.text: The feeding of the five thousand.
The healing of Simon's mother-in-law.
The expulsion of an unclean spirit from the synagogue in Capernaum.
The calm of the storm on the lake.

explanation: Mark reports that after Jesus began his ministry in Galilee, he taught in the synagogue of Capernaum, where he healed a man who had an unclean spirit, which amazed those present.
verseTextContent: Just then there was a man in their synagogue who was under the power of an unclean spirit, and he shouted: “What have we to do with you, Jesus the Naz·a·reneʹ? Did you come to destroy us? I know exactly who you are, the Holy One of God!” But Jesus rebuked it, saying: “Be silent, and come out of him!” And the unclean spirit, after throwing the man into a convulsion and yelling at the top of its voice, came out of him.

question: In the parable of the unjust judge and the widow (Luke 18): What main quality is illustrated by the widow's conduct that Christians should imitate in prayer?

options.text: Patience in Suffering
Persistence and perseverance in prayer without giving up.
The ability to convince others.
The Offerings

explanation: Jesus told this parable to show that the widow who persisted in praying and not giving up, who kept pressing the unjust judge to get her justice, was an example of perseverance in prayer, trusting that God would hear his chosen ones.
verseTextContent: Then he went on to tell them an illustration about the need for them always to pray and not to give up,

question: What counsel did Jesus give at Luke 14:12-14 regarding inviting guests to a meal?

options.text: You should only invite your rich neighbors to gain fame.
When you are hosting a meal, do not invite your friends, brothers, relatives, or rich neighbors. Instead, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind.
You should always throw a big party for the whole town.
You should only invite those who have invited you.

explanation: Jesus taught that genuine generosity and hospitality are shown in inviting those who cannot repay. Such unselfish gifts will be rewarded at the resurrection of the righteous.
verseTextContent: Next he said also to the man who had invited him: “When you spread a dinner or an evening meal, do not call your friends or your brothers or your relatives or your rich neighbors. Otherwise, they might also invite you in return, and it would become a repayment to you. But when you spread a feast, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind; and you will be happy, because they have nothing with which to repay you. For you will be repaid in the resurrection of the righteous ones.”

question: According to John 11, what happened when Jesus came to the tomb of his friend Lazarus, who had been dead for four days?

options.text: He prayed and Lazarus' spirit returned.
He wept, removed the stone, and called out with a loud voice: "Lazarus, come out!" at which point the dead man came out alive.
He anointed the body and prepared it for an honorable burial.
He gave a long sermon on the resurrection.

explanation: Although Lazarus had been in the tomb for four days, Jesus raised him to life, which led many witnesses to believe in him and also increased the enmity of the religious leaders.
verseTextContent: When he had said these things, he cried out with a loud voice: “Lazʹa·rus, come out!” The man who had been dead came out with his feet and hands bound with wrappings, and his face was wrapped with a cloth. Jesus said to them: “Free him and let him go.”

question: After Peter had repeatedly affirmed his love for Jesus, what commission did the resurrected Jesus give the apostle Peter at the Sea of Tiberias three times?

options.text: "Go and preach to all the nations.
Shepherd my lambs. Shepherd my little sheep.
Build my congregation upon this rock.
Don't be afraid, just believe.

explanation: After Peter denied Jesus, Jesus gave him the opportunity to confirm his love, and each time Jesus gave him the responsibility of caring for his followers ("lambs", "sheep"), feeding and guiding them spiritually.
verseTextContent: When they had finished breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter: “Simon son of John, do you love me more than these?” He replied to him: “Yes, Lord, you know I have affection for you.” He said to him: “Feed my lambs.” Again he said to him a second time: “Simon son of John, do you love me?” He replied: “Yes, Lord, you know I have affection for you.” He said to him: “Shepherd my little sheep.” He said to him a third time: “Simon son of John, do you have affection for me?” Peter became grieved that he asked him the third time: “Do you have affection for me?” So he said to him: “Lord, you are aware of all things; you know that I have affection for you.” Jesus said to him: “Feed my little sheep.

question: At John 10:16, what did Jesus say about "other sheep" not of this flock (Israel)?

options.text: That they should be ignored.
"I have other sheep that are not of this fold. I must bring them also, and they will listen to my voice, and they will become one flock with one shepherd.
That they won't come to him until after the trial.
That they'd have another shepherd.

explanation: Jesus pointed out that his work of deliverance and care would not be limited to the Jews, but that he would gather "other sheep" (non-Jews) and bring them together into a united flock under his direction as one shepherd.
verseTextContent: “And I have other sheep, which are not of this fold; those too I must bring in, and they will listen to my voice, and they will become one flock, one shepherd.

question: (John 17) What was one of his chief requests to the Father regarding their unity?

options.text: That they should all have the same opinion.
that they may all be one, just as he and the Father are one, so that the world may believe that the Father has sent him.
That they should start a global organization.
That they would never argue.

explanation: A central concern of Jesus in his high priestly prayer was the unity of his followers, which was to reflect the perfect unity between him and his Father and serve as a powerful witness to the world confirming Jesus' divine mission.
verseTextContent: “I make request, not concerning these only, but also concerning those putting faith in me through their word, so that they may all be one, just as you, Father, are in union with me and I am in union with you, that they also may be in union with us, so that the world may believe that you sent me.

question: What relationship does "the Word" have with God, and what was it itself?

options.text: THE word was another name for the Holy Spirit.
In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was a god.
THE Word was an angel who later became God.
THE Word was God the Father himself in a different form.

explanation: John begins his Gospel with a profound statement about "the Word" (Jesus Christ in his prehuman existence), which existed from the beginning, had a close relationship with God (the Father), and had a divine nature ('was a God' or 'was divine').
verseTextContent: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was a god.

question: What is the "sacred secret" (or "mystery") that Paul speaks of and is particularly revealed in the Gospel of John, namely, the role of Christ in God's purpose?

options.text: The exact method of performing miracles.

The fact that Christ, the Word, became man to reveal God's glory and love, to bring salvation, and to serve as mediator of the new covenant, fulfilling God's long-hidden purpose to save mankind and to unite all things in him.
The secret teachings that Jesus gave only to his closest disciples.
The exact time of Armageddon.

explanation: The "holy secret" refers to aspects of God's purpose that were hidden in the Old Testament and were not fully revealed until Jesus Christ and the apostles, and a central aspect of this secret that John highlights is Christ's incarnation, his role as the revealing God, the Redeemer, and the means by which God's universal purpose is realized.
verse: Ephesians 3:4-6; Kolosser 1:26-27 (als Erläuterung des Begriffs 'heiliges Geheimnis', das Johannes entfaltet)
verseTextContent: So when you read this, you can realize my comprehension of the sacred secret of the Christ. In other generations this secret was not made known to the sons of men as it has now been revealed to his holy apostles and prophets by spirit, namely, that people of the nations should, in union with Christ Jesus and through the good news, be joint heirs and fellow members of the body and partakers with us of the promise.

question: What is Paul's call on Christians at Romans 12:2 regarding their mind?

options.text: To adapt to the world's standards, to better respond to people.
To be transformed by the re-forming of their minds, not by the molding of this system of things.
To focus your mind on wealth and success.
To expand your sense through philosophical studies, to try to elevate your inner mind to be like God.

explanation: Paul urges Christians not to conform to worldly patterns of thinking and behavior but to strive for an inner transformation by renewing their thinking in order to know and do God's will.
verseTextContent: And stop being molded by this system of things, but be transformed by making your mind over, so that you may prove to yourselves the good and acceptable and perfect will of God.

question: What is evident in God's creation, even though God himself is invisible, as stated at Romans 1:20?

options.text: The exact time of the end of the world.
His invisible qualities, his eternal power and divinity, have been clearly seen since the creation of the world, as they are perceived by the things he has made.
The name of all the angels.
Secret messages for the chosen.

explanation: Paul argues that creation itself bears clear witness to God's existence and attributes, his eternal power and divine nature being evident in the works of his creation, so that humans have no excuse for not acknowledging him.
verseTextContent: For his invisible qualities are clearly seen from the world’s creation onward, because they are perceived by the things made, even his eternal power and Godship, so that they are inexcusable.

question: What counsel does Paul give in Romans 14 regarding dealing with fellow believers who have different views on matters of conscience (such as certain meals or days)?

options.text: The "weak in faith" should be corrected and forced to accept their own viewpoint.
To welcome the weak in your faith, but not with a view to disputing opinions. Do not condemn the one who eats, nor the one who does not eat, for God has accepted him.
Avoid contact with those who have different views.
We should set a uniform rule for all.

explanation: Paul exhorts Christians to be tolerant and loving of one another in matters not involving basic doctrines of faith, not to judge or despise one another because of different consciences, but to promote peace and the upbuilding of the congregation.
verseTextContent: Welcome the man having weaknesses in his faith, but do not pass judgment on differing opinions.

question: In Romans chapter 7, Paul describes an inner conflict.

options.text: A conflict between his desire to become rich and his desire to serve God.
The struggle between his renewed mind, which enjoys God's law, and the "law of sin" in his members, which drives him to do what he does not want (the bad) and to do what he does not want to do.
A doubt about the resurrection of Christ.
A dispute with other apostles over doctrinal matters.

explanation: Paul describes the ongoing struggle of a born-again Christian against his inherent sinful nature. Although he delights in God's law and wants to do what is right, he feels another law within him that draws him to sin, leading to the cry: 'Woe to me, poor man! Who will deliver me from the body that is causing death?'
verseTextContent: I really delight in the law of God according to the man I am within, but I see in my body another law warring against the law of my mind and leading me captive to sin’s law that is in my body. Miserable man that I am! Who will rescue me from the body undergoing this death? Thanks to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So, then, with my mind I myself am a slave to God’s law, but with my flesh to sin’s law.

question: What is God's sovereign plan for Israel and the admission of Gentiles (non-Jews) into his people, according to Romans chapters 9-11?

options.text: That God has rejected Israel and turned to the Gentiles.

Although much of natural Israel rejected the Messiah, God did not reject his people permanently. His promises continue to apply to a faithful remnant. Israel's temporary disobedience opened the door to salvation to the nations (symbolized by the grafting of wild branches into the fine olive tree), which would eventually lead to the envy and salvation of many Israelites, so that God's mercy might be shown to all.
That only native-born Jews can be saved.
That God no longer has a specific plan for Israel.

explanation: Paul is dealing with the question of the unbelief of many of his Jewish countrymen, showing that God's promises have not failed, but that his sovereignty and mercy are shown in preserving a remnant of Israel and in bringing people from the nations to his salvation.
verseTextContent: I ask, then, God did not reject his people, did he? By no means! For I too am an Israelite, of the offspring of Abraham, from the tribe of Benjamin.

question: What quality, as described by Paul in 1 Corinthians chapter 13, is the greatest and most imperishable of all gifts?

options.text: Prophecy
Faith
The love (agápē).
Knowledge

explanation: In the famous "Song of Love", Paul presents love as the most outstanding and enduring Christian virtue. Even when the gifts of prophecy, speech, or knowledge cease, love remains.
verseTextContent: Now, however, these three remain: faith, hope, love; but the greatest of these is love.

question: What admonition does Paul give the Corinthians before they partake of the Lord's Evening Meal, as recorded at 1 Corinthians 11:28?

options.text: Eat fast to save time.
Then each one must examine himself and eat of the bread and drink of the cup.
Just a little bit to eat.
Waiting for an apostle to be present.

explanation: In view of the grievances at the Last Supper in Corinth, Paul stresses the need for self-examination, so that each individual should examine his heart and conduct to make sure that he is partaking in a way that honors Christ and understands the meaning of the meal, so as not to eat and drink it in an unworthy way.
verseTextContent: Therefore, whoever eats the loaf or drinks the cup of the Lord unworthily will be guilty respecting the body and the blood of the Lord. First let a man approve himself after scrutiny, and only then let him eat of the loaf and drink of the cup.

question: What counsel does Paul give regarding the body of a Christian at 1 Corinthians 6:19-20?

options.text: That the body is unimportant and you don't have to worry about it.
The body of a Christian is a temple of the Spirit who lives in him. It is not his own, but it was bought at a price. Therefore let him glorify God in his body.
That you should cast your body through strict asceticism.
That the body is destroyed after death and doesn't matter.

explanation: Paul exhorted the Corinthians to avoid sexual immorality, reminding them that their bodies are a temple of the holy spirit that dwells in them, so that they may honor God with their bodies, since they belong to Christ, who bought them with his blood.
verseTextContent: Do you not know that your body is the temple of the holy spirit within you, which you have from God? Also, you do not belong to yourselves, for you were bought with a price. By all means, glorify God in your body.

question: What does Paul say at 1 Corinthians 10:13 about temptations facing Christians?

options.text: That sometimes God sends temptations that are too hard.

No temptation has come upon you except one that is common to men. But God is faithful, and he will not let you be tempted beyond what you can handle. When temptation strikes you, he will also provide the way out so that you can endure it.
That the best way to escape temptation is to escape.
That only weak Christians are tempted.

explanation: Paul gives an important assurance: The temptations that Christians face are typical of humans. God is faithful and will not allow them to be tempted beyond their strength.
verseTextContent: No temptation has come upon you except what is common to men. But God is faithful, and he will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear, but along with the temptation he will also make the way out so that you may be able to endure it.

question: In 1 Corinthians chapters 1 and 2, Paul contrasted "the wisdom of this world" (or of men) with "the wisdom of God in a sacred secret".

options.text: In complex philosophical systems.

For in Christ, crucified, the message of the cross, that God redeems us through the seemingly weak and shameful death of his Son, is foolishness to the wise of this world, but God's power and wisdom to those who are called.
In secret rituals and mysteries.
In political power and military strength.

explanation: Paul acknowledges that God's way of salvation through the death of Jesus Christ on the cross is contrary to the standards of human wisdom. It is a stumbling block to the Jews and a foolishness to the Greeks, but to those who are called it is the expression of God's supreme power and wisdom in Christ.
verseTextContent: For the speech about the torture stake is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved, it is God’s power.

question: What does Paul say at 2 Corinthians 4:18 about the things Christians should look to?

options.text: To the visible, material things.
For we do not look to the things seen, but to the things not seen. For the things seen are temporary, but the things not seen are eternal.
To their own achievements and achievements.
The mistakes and weaknesses of others.

explanation: Paul draws the focus of believers from the transient, visible things of this world to the eternal, invisible realities of the spirit and of God's Kingdom.
verseTextContent: while we keep our eyes, not on the things seen, but on the things unseen. For the things seen are temporary, but the things unseen are everlasting.

question: What service or task does Paul refer to at 2 Corinthians 5:18-20 as the "minister of reconciliation"?

options.text: The medical service.
The ministry of Christ's representative to ask people to 'reconcile themselves with God' by proclaiming the message of reconciliation through Christ.
The service of raising money for the poor.
The ministry of appointing congregation elders.

explanation: After God has reconciled mankind to himself through Christ, he has entrusted the "ministering of the reconciliation" to Christians, who, as Christ's ambassadors, ask others in God's name to accept that reconciliation and to repair their relationship with God.
verseTextContent: But all things are from God, who reconciled us to himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of the reconciliation, namely, that God was by means of Christ reconciling a world to himself, not counting their offenses against them, and he entrusted to us the message of the reconciliation. Therefore, we are ambassadors substituting for Christ, as though God were making an appeal through us. As substitutes for Christ, we beg: “Become reconciled to God.”

question: What does Paul mean when he says at 2 Corinthians 12:9 that God's power is made "perfect in weakness"?

options.text: That you must first sin to experience God's power.
That it is only when Christians are aware of their own human weakness and inadequacy and rely on God that his power can be most powerful and manifested in and through them.
That physical weakness is a sign of mental strength.
That God chooses only weak people for his service.

explanation: Paul learned through his "thorn in the flesh" that God's power is perfected in human weakness. If we recognize our own limitations and do not rely on our own strength, God's power can work unhindered in us and accomplish his purposes for glory.
verseTextContent: But he said to me: “My undeserved kindness is sufficient for you, for my power is being made perfect in weakness.” Most gladly, then, I will boast about my weaknesses, in order that the power of the Christ may remain over me like a tent.

question: What kind of sorrow is "sorrow according to God's will", and what does it do in contrast with "sorrow of the world"? (2 Corinthians 7:10) How does it affect us?

options.text: A sadness that leads to despair.
For sorrow according to God's will produces repentance for salvation, which is unrepentant; but the sorrow of the world produces death.
A sadness over lost material goods.
A sadness that is only shown on the outside.

explanation: Paul distinguishes between two kinds of grief over mistakes made: God-ordained grief that leads to true repentance, repentance, and ultimate salvation; worldly grief, on the other hand, is often characterized by self-pity or fear of consequences and leads not to positive change but to despair and death.
verseTextContent: For sadness in a godly way produces repentance leading to salvation, leaving no regret; but the sadness of the world produces death.

question: At 2 Corinthians 4:7, Paul speaks of Christians having the "treasure" of service "in earthly vessels".

options.text: That service is worthless and fragile.

The "treasure " is the glorious gospel and the ministry entrusted to them. The " earthly vessels " are the imperfect and weak bodies of God's servants, so that the power beyond all things may come from God and not from themselves.
That Christians should hide their spiritual treasures.
That the service is only for a short time.

explanation: The precious "treasure" of the ministry of the gospel and of the knowledge of God is entrusted to imperfect humans ("earthly vessels"). This contrast between the value of the treasure and the fragility of the vessels shows that the power that is effective in the ministry is not of human origin but that it comes from God, so that he is worthy of honor.
verseTextContent: However, we have this treasure in earthen vessels, so that the power beyond what is normal may be God’s and not from us.

question: What "new covenant" does Paul mention at 2 Corinthians 3:6, of which he and his associates have become ministers, and how does it differ from the "written code" (the Mosaic Law)?

options.text: A covenant based on even stricter written rules.
It is not a written covenant, but a spiritual one. The written one condemns to death, but the spirit gives life. This new covenant is through Christ the mediator of righteousness and forgiveness.
A covenant that only applies to non-Jews.
A secret covenant known to only a select few.

explanation: Paul contrasted the old covenant (the Law of Moses), which was based on written commandments and ultimately exposed sin and condemned it to death, with the new covenant, mediated by Christ and effective through the holy spirit, which brings life, forgiveness, and inner transformation because God's law is "written in the hearts".
verseTextContent: who has indeed adequately qualified us to be ministers of a new covenant, not of a written code, but of spirit; for the written code condemns to death, but the spirit makes alive.

question: What special service did young Samuel perform at the tabernacle under the supervision of High Priest Eli?

options.text: He was responsible for preparing the sacrifices and helping in the battles.
He was serving Jehovah, wearing a linen ephod, and in the morning he opened the doors of Jehovah's house.
And he taught the sons of Eli according to the law of Moses, and prepared them for the priesthood.
He was the personal mouthpiece of High Priest Eli and kept watch over the ark of the covenant at night.

explanation: Samuel was a young man when he was serving in the tabernacle at Shiloh, wearing a linen ephod, a priestly garment, and doing various duties, such as opening the doors of the sanctuary, under the direction of Elisha.
verseTextContent: Now Samuel was ministering before Jehovah, wearing a linen ephʹod, though he was just a boy.

question: Why did Jehovah reject Saul as king over Israel, as Samuel told him?

options.text: Because Saul was too old to lead the people effectively and to defeat Israel's enemies.
Because he made a peace treaty with the Philistines without consulting Jehovah.
Because he had rejected Jehovah's Word, especially by his disobedience toward the Amalekites and his self-righteous act of sacrifice.
Because the people were demanding a new, younger king from the tribe of Judah.

explanation: Key events included his own sacrifice before a battle and his refusal to completely banish the Amalekites and their possessions as Jehovah had commanded.
verseTextContent: Samuel then said: “Does Jehovah take as much pleasure in burnt offerings and sacrifices as in obeying the voice of Jehovah? Look! To obey is better than a sacrifice, and to pay attention than the fat of rams; for rebelliousness is the same as the sin of divination, and pushing ahead presumptuously the same as using magical power and idolatry. Because you have rejected the word of Jehovah, he has rejected you from being king.”

question: What special ability of David led to his being called to serve King Saul's court?

options.text: His extraordinary strength in battle, which he had already proved as a shepherd.
His prophetic gift of foretelling the future and interpreting dreams.
His ability to play the harp, which he used to calm down Saul, who was plagued by an evil spirit.
His diplomatic skills in dealing with the surrounding peoples.

explanation: When King Saul was frightened by an evil spirit from Jehovah, his servants sought someone who could play the harp well to calm him down.
verseTextContent: Let our lord, please, command your servants before you to look for a man who is skilled at playing the harp. Whenever a bad spirit from God comes upon you, he will play it, and you will feel better.”

question: What was the main cause of Saul's growing enmity and jealousy toward David?

options.text: David came from a rival tribe and threatened Saul's authority.
David's military successes and his growing popularity among the people ("Saul struck his thousands and David his tens of thousands"), which Saul saw as a threat to his kingship.
A direct command from Jehovah to follow David to test his faith.
David refused to marry Saul's daughter Michal and to make covenants with him.

explanation: After David defeated Goliath and celebrated further military victories, the women of Israel sang in his honor, which made Saul jealous and suspicious.
verseTextContent: The women who were celebrating would sing: “Saul has struck down his thousands,And David his tens of thousands.” Saul became very angry, and this song displeased him, for he said: “They have credited David with tens of thousands, but to me they have credited thousands. The only thing left to give him is the kingship!” From that day on, Saul was always looking at David suspiciously.

question: In despair, King Saul took what forbidden action before his final battle with the Philistines at Gilboa after Jehovah stopped answering him?

options.text: He tried to negotiate a peace treaty with the Philistines and offered them gold.
He made a covenant with the surrounding pagan nations to obtain military support.
He consulted a spirit medium in En-dor to ask the late prophet Samuel for advice, even though he had himself exterminated the spirit mediums from the land.
He sacrificed his own son Jonathan to win back Jehovah's favor.

explanation: When the Philistines pressured Saul and he received no answer from Jehovah through dreams, Urim, or prophets, he desperately sought out a spirit medium at En-dor to communicate with the dead Samuel, a serious violation of Jehovah's law against spiritism.
verseTextContent: Although Saul would inquire of Jehovah, Jehovah never answered him, either in dreams or by the Uʹrim or through the prophets. Finally Saul said to his servants: “Find me a woman who is a spirit medium, and I will go and consult her.” His servants replied: “Look! There is a woman who is a spirit medium in En-dor.” So Saul disguised himself and put on other garments and went to the woman by night with two of his men. He said: “Use divination, please, by acting as a spirit medium, and bring up for me the one whom I designate to you.”

question: What attitude did David display several times when he had the opportunity to kill King Saul, who unjustly persecuted him?

options.text: He immediately seized the opportunity to remove Saul and to become king himself, since he had already been anointed.
He refused to raise his hand against Saul, Jehovah's anointed one, and left it to Jehovah to judge and act, despite pressure from his men.
He wounded Saul badly to make him fit for battle, but he did not kill him directly.
He took Saul captive and handed him over to the Philistines to protect himself.

explanation: Despite the life-threatening persecution of Saul and several attempts to kill him (e.g., in the cave at En-gedi or in Saul's camp), David refused to harm Saul, showing his deep respect for God's chosen authority by respecting Saul as Jehovah's appointed king and leaving the judgment to Jehovah.
verseTextContent: David’s men said to him: “This is the day on which Jehovah is saying to you, ‘Look! I am giving your enemy into your hand, and you can do to him whatever seems good to you.’” So David rose up and quietly cut off the edge of Saul’s sleeveless coat. But afterward David’s heart kept striking him because he had cut off the edge of Saul’s sleeveless coat. He said to his men: “It is unthinkable from Jehovah’s standpoint that I should do such a thing to my lord, the anointed of Jehovah, by lifting my hand against him, for he is the anointed of Jehovah.” So David restrained his men with these words, and he did not allow them to attack Saul. As for Saul, he rose up from the cave and went on his way.

question: How did David react when he heard the news of Saul and Jonathan's death in the battle against the Philistines?

options.text: He was glad that his main pursuer had been eliminated and that the way to the throne had been cleared.
And he rent his garments, and mourned, and wept, and fasted, and wrote a lamentation for Saul and Jonathan, and put to death the messenger who told Saul that he had killed him.
He immediately moved to Jerusalem to be crowned king over all Israel.
He sent an army to punish the Philistines for Saul's death.

explanation: David expressed deep sorrow and respect for the death of his persecutor Saul and his beloved friend Jonathan, and his lamentation in 2 Samuel 1 expresses his grief.
verseTextContent: At this David took hold of his garments and ripped them apart, and so did all the men who were with him. And they wailed and wept and fasted until evening for Saul, for his son Jonʹa·than, for the people of Jehovah, and for the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.

question: As recorded in 2 Samuel chapter 6, what important religious act did David perform after he conquered Jerusalem and made it its capital?

options.text: He immediately built the temple for Jehovah.
He brought Jehovah's covenant ark to Jerusalem in great joy and sacrifice to the City of David.
He appointed new high priests.
He wrote the whole book of Psalms.

explanation: David's primary concern was to bring the ark of the covenant, which symbolized Jehovah's presence, to his new capital, Jerusalem.
verseTextContent: The report was made to King David: “Jehovah has blessed the house of Oʹbed-eʹdom and all that belongs to him because of the Ark of the true God.” So David went to bring the Ark of the true God from the house of Oʹbed-eʹdom up to the City of David with rejoicing.

question: What prophet did David confront with his sin regarding Bath-sheba and Uriah by an illustration?

options.text: The prophet Samuel who appeared to him.
The prophet Gad, who often gave him advice.
The prophet Nathan told him the parable of the rich man and the poor man's lamb.
The high priest Abjathar.

explanation: When David spoke of the rich man's death sentence in anger, Nathan said: 'You yourself are the man!' and thus exposed David's sin.
verseTextContent: So Jehovah sent Nathan to David. He came in to him and said: “There were two men in one city, the one rich and the other poor.

question: What was the result of Absalom's rebellion, although he was successful at first and expelled David from Jerusalem?

options.text: He was pardoned by David and allowed to continue as a prince.
He was defeated in the battle in the forest of Ephraim, his long hair fell in the branches of a large tree, and he was killed by Joab and his men.
He fled to another country and never returned.
He made peace with David and divided the kingdom.

explanation: And David commanded his captains of the army to be gracious to Absalom; but Absalom's army was defeated in the battle, and he hung himself with his head upon a tree, and was slain by Joab; and David mourned deeply.
verseTextContent: Abʹsa·lom eventually found himself facing the servants of David. Abʹsa·lom was riding on a mule, and the mule went under the thick branches of a large tree, and his head got entangled in the big tree, so that he was suspended in midair while the mule he had been riding kept going.

question: At 2 Samuel 24, David had a census that Jehovah displeased him with. What three punitive options did Jehovah offer David through the prophet Gad, and which did he choose?

options.text: A severe illness, a famine, or a defeat against his enemies; David chose the disease.

Seven years of famine in the land, three months of flight from his enemies, or three days of pestilence in the land; David chose the pestilence because he preferred to fall into the hand of Jehovah, whose mercy is great.
The loss of his kingdom, the destruction of Jerusalem, or the death of his firstborn son; David chose the death of his son.
An earthquake, a drought, or an attack by wild animals; David could not decide.

explanation: After David acknowledged his sin in the census, Jehovah offered three punitive options through Gad, who chose the three-day plague because he preferred to fall into the hands of Jehovah, whose mercy is great, rather than into the hands of men.
verseTextContent: “Go and say to David, ‘This is what Jehovah says: “I am giving you three options. Choose the one that I should bring on you.”’” So Gad came in to David and told him: “Should seven years of famine come on your land? Or should you flee for three months from your adversaries while they pursue you? Or should there be three days of pestilence in your land? Now consider carefully what I should reply to the One who sent me.” So David said to Gad: “It is very distressing to me. Let us fall, please, into the hand of Jehovah, for his mercy is great; but do not let me fall into the hand of man.”

question: Who was Abner, and what role did he play in the period after Saul's death before David became king over all Israel?

options.text: A prophet who anointed David king.

Saul's army leader, who after Saul's death appointed his son Ish-bosheth as king of Israel (the northern tribes), first fighting David and Judah but later trying to overrun David before being killed by Joab.
A priest who brought the ark of the covenant to Jerusalem.
A son of David who tried to take the throne.

explanation: And Abner was a relative of Saul, and the chief of his army; and after Saul's death he made Ish-bosheth the son of Saul, who was left, king over the tribes of Israel; and David reigned over Judah in Hebron. And there was war between the men of David and Ish-bosheth. And Abner fought with Ish-bosheth, and he came to David to make all Israel his king; but Joab the captain of David's army slew him.
verseTextContent: But Abʹner the son of Ner, the chief of Saul’s army, had taken Saul’s son Ish-boʹsheth and brought him across to Ma·ha·naʹim and made him king over Gilʹe·ad, the Ashʹur·ites, Jezʹre·el, Eʹphra·im, Benjamin, and over all Israel.

question: According to Acts chapter 2, what event occurred at Pentecost in Jerusalem after Jesus' disciples had gathered together?

options.text: Jesus appeared to them again and gave them final instructions for their ministry.
They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in different tongues, as the Spirit gave them the ability to speak.
A great earthquake shook the city and opened the prison doors to many believers.
The apostles chose Matthias, who was to succeed Judas Iscariot.

explanation: At Pentecost, about 120 of the disciples were filled with the Holy Spirit, and a sound like a strong breeze and tongues like fire appeared, so that they spoke in the tongues of the Jews living in the land.
verseTextContent: and they all became filled with holy spirit and started to speak in different languages, just as the spirit enabled them to speak.

question: Who gave the first great sermon after the outpouring of the holy spirit, which led to the baptism of about three thousand people?

options.text: The apostle John, known as "the disciple whom Jesus loved", spoke particularly eloquently.
The apostle Paul after converting on the road to Damascus.
The apostle Peter stood up boldly and declared Jesus to the crowd as the Christ and Lord.
Before being stoned, Stephen gave a long talk about the history of Israel.

explanation: When they had finished speaking in tongues, Peter stood up and explained to the crowd, who were amazed, that this was the fulfillment of the prophecy of Joel, and that Jesus, whom they had crucified, was both Lord and Christ.
verseTextContent: But Peter stood up with the Eleven and spoke to them in a loud voice: “Men of Ju·deʹa and all you inhabitants of Jerusalem, let this be known to you and listen carefully to my words.

question: What counsel did the respected law teacher Gamaliel give to the Sanhedrin when the apostles were again arrested for continuing to preach about Jesus?

options.text: He advised the apostles to be immediately executed in order to stifle the new teaching.
He recommended that they be whipped and then banned from ever teaching again in Jerusalem.

He cautioned them, "If this work was man - made, it would have been destroyed by itself. But if it were from God, they would not be able to fight it, but would be fighting against God. Therefore let them go".
He proposed sending the apostles into exile to banish their teachings from Judea.

explanation: Gamaliel, a Pharisee who was highly respected among the people, advised the Sanhedrin to restrain itself, reminding them of the earlier rebellion, whose movements had collapsed after their deaths. He argued that if the work of the apostles were of human origin, it would also fail. But if it were from God, they could not stop it and would be fighting against God.
verseTextContent: So under the present circumstances, I say to you, do not meddle with these men, but let them alone. For if this scheme or this work is from men, it will be overthrown; but if it is from God, you will not be able to overthrow them. Otherwise, you may even be found fighters against God himself.”

question: Who was the first Christian martyr to be stoned after giving a powerful speech before the Sanhedrin?

options.text: The apostle James, the brother of John, was murdered at a feast in honor of Herod.
Now Stephen, one of the seven men chosen to distribute the daily distribution of the widows, was a man of faith and of the Holy Spirit.
Barnabas, who accompanied Paul on his travels.
The apostle Andrew, the brother of Peter.

explanation: When Stephen, a man known for his wisdom and miraculous deeds, was accused by false witnesses, he gave a long talk in the Sanhedrin, accusing the leaders of their rebellion and the murder of the Christ. Then he was led out of the city in anger and stoned.
verseTextContent: After throwing him outside the city, they began stoning him. The witnesses laid down their outer garments at the feet of a young man called Saul. As they were stoning Stephen, he made this appeal: “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.” Then, kneeling down, he cried out with a strong voice: “Jehovah, do not charge this sin against them.” And after saying this, he fell asleep in death.

question: As recorded in Acts chapter 15, what important decision did the "congregation and the apostles and the older men" in Jerusalem make regarding the Gentile believers?

options.text: That Gentiles must first accept Jewish citizenship to become Christians.
That circumcision and keeping the Mosaic Law were not a requirement for salvation for Gentiles, but that they should abstain from idolatry, blood, strangled animals and fornication.
That Gentiles should form their own congregations separate from Jewish Christians.
That Gentiles must follow all Jewish food laws in order to be considered pure.

explanation: When the apostles and elders in Jerusalem heard that some Jews were required to be circumcised, they came together and were led by Peter and Paul to decide that no such burden should be placed on the Gentiles except on some things that were necessary.
verseTextContent: For the holy spirit and we ourselves have favored adding no further burden to you except these necessary things: to keep abstaining from things sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what is strangled, and from sexual immorality. If you carefully keep yourselves from these things, you will prosper. Good health to you!”

question: What group of craftsmen in Ephesus stirred up a riot against Paul because his preaching threatened their idolatry and business?

options.text: The fishermen, because he disturbed their fishing grounds.
The tentmakers who were competing with Paul.
The silversmiths, led by Demetrius, made silver shrines of the goddess Artemis, fearing that their trade would be discredited by Paul's teaching.
The pottery, whose vessels he called unclean.

explanation: Paul's preaching at Ephesus was so successful that many burned their idols. Demetrius, a silversmith who made models of the temple of Artemis, saw his business and the worship of Artemis at risk. He persuaded the other craftsmen, causing a great disturbance in the city.
verseTextContent: For a man named De·meʹtri·us, a silversmith who made silver shrines of Arʹte·mis, brought considerable profit to the craftsmen. He gathered them and others who worked at such things and said: “Men, you well know that from this business comes our prosperity. Now you see and hear how, not only in Ephʹe·sus but in nearly all the province of Asia, this Paul has persuaded a considerable crowd and turned them to another opinion, saying that the gods made by hands are not really gods. Moreover, the danger exists not only that this business of ours will come into disrepute but also that the temple of the great goddess Arʹte·mis will be viewed as nothing, and she who is worshipped in the whole province of Asia and the inhabited earth will be deprived of her magnificence.”

question: What Babylonian name was given to Daniel when he and his friends were brought up in Nebuchadnezzar's court?

Beltshassar
Other articles of heading No.

explanation: Daniel was named by the chief courtier of the king of Babylon, Belteshazzar, and his three friends, Hananiah, Michael, and Azariah, were named Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego.
verseTextContent: And the principal court official assigned names to them; he gave to Daniel the name Bel·te·shazʹzar, to Han·a·niʹah the name Shaʹdrach, to Mishʹa·el the name Meʹshach, and to Az·a·riʹah the name A·bedʹne·go.

question: What mysterious writing appeared on the wall during King Belshazzar's banquet that only Daniel could interpret?

options.text: A warning of an impending earthquake and a great flood.
A series of incomprehensible symbols that Daniel pointed to as a prophecy about future kings.
The words 'MENE, MENE, TEKEL, and PARSIN,' which meant that God had numbered, weighed, and divided the kingdom of Belshazzar, and had given it to the Medes and Persians.
A song of praise to the gods of Babylon, but which Daniel exposed as blasphemy.

explanation: While Belshazzar was celebrating with the holy vessels of Jehovah's temple, a hand appeared and wrote four words on the wall, which Daniel interpreted as God's judgment upon Belshazzar and his kingdom: It was counted and found to be finished, invented in a scale too lightly and would be divided and given to the Medes and Persians.
verseTextContent: And this is the writing that was inscribed: MEʹNE, MEʹNE, TEʹKEL, and PARʹSIN. “This is the interpretation of the words: MEʹNE, God has numbered the days of your kingdom and brought it to an end. “TEʹKEL, you have been weighed in the balances and found lacking. “PEʹRES, your kingdom has been divided and given to the Medes and the Persians.”

question: What vision of Daniel chapter 7 shows four great beasts coming up from the sea, representing successive world powers?

options.text: A vision of seven angels with trumpets announcing God's judgment.
A lion with eagle wings (Babylon), a bear (Medo-Persia), a leopard with four wings and four heads (Greece), and a fourth, fearful beast with iron teeth and ten horns (Rome and its aftermath).
A vision of a giant statue made of various metals that also symbolized world powers.
A vision of a battle between a ram and a goat, representing Medo-Persian and Greek.

explanation: Daniel saw in a night vision four different beasts, symbolizing world powers, beginning with Babylon, and also showing how the "Old One of Days" (Jehovah) was judging and giving "the Son of man" (Jesus Christ) everlasting rulership over all nations.
verseTextContent: And four huge beasts came out of the sea, each different from the others. “The first one was like a lion, and it had the wings of an eagle. I watched until its wings were plucked out, and it was lifted up from the earth and was made to stand up on two feet like a man, and it was given the heart of a man. “And look! another beast, a second one, like a bear. It was raised up on one side, and three ribs were in its mouth between its teeth; and it was told, ‘Get up, eat much flesh.’ “After this I kept watching, and look! another beast, like a leopard, but on its back it had four wings like those of a bird. And the beast had four heads, and it was given authority to rule. “After this I kept watching in the visions of the night, and I saw a fourth beast, fearsome and terrifying and unusually strong, and it had large iron teeth. It was devouring and crushing, and what was left it trampled down with its feet. It was different from all the other beasts that were prior to it, and it had ten horns.

question: What was the content of Nebuchadnezzar's dream about the great tree that was cut down, and how did Daniel interpret this dream?

options.text: The tree represented the Babylonian Empire that would last forever.

The tree represented Nebuchadnezzar's own royal rule, and the cutting down of the tree meant that Nebuchadnezzar would be removed from his throne for "seven times", rejected by humans, and live like an animal until he recognized that the Supreme Ruler is in the kingdom of mankind.
The tree symbolized the temple in Jerusalem that was to be destroyed.
The tree represented a future world ruler who would be overthrown.

explanation: The tree's cutting down with the remaining trunk meant that Nebuchadnezzar would lose his royal rule for a period of "seven times" and be humiliated until he acknowledged God's sovereignty.
verseTextContent: “‘The tree that you saw that grew great and became strong, whose top reached the heavens and was visible to all the earth, which had beautiful foliage, abundant fruit, and food for all, beneath which the beasts of the field would dwell and on whose branches the birds of the heavens would reside, it is you, O king, because you have grown great and become strong, and your grandeur has grown and reached to the heavens, and your rulership to the ends of the earth.

question: Daniel chapter 11 prophesy a long-standing conflict between the "king of the north" and the "king of the south". What general identity have these two rival powers throughout history, as understood by many Bible publishers, including Jehovah's Witnesses?

options.text: They're always just Egypt and Syria.

It is a succession of dominant political powers, located north or south of God's people (originally Israel, later Christendom in the translated sense), fighting for world domination, whose identity changed over time (e.g., Seleucids vs. Ptolemy, Rome vs. its rivals, to modern power blocs).
They symbolize the struggle between good and evil in the heart of every human being.
They refer exclusively to angelic powers in the invisible realm.

explanation: The prophecy of the king of the north and the king of the south describes a long chain of conflicts between rival political powers. The specific identity of these "kings" has changed over the centuries, but they each represent the dominant power north or south of the country where God's people were based or at the center of the prophecy.
verse: Daniel 11:40 (als Beispiel für die Endzeitphase dieses Konflikts)
verseTextContent: “In the time of the end the king of the south will engage with him in a pushing, and against him the king of the north will storm with chariots and horsemen and many ships; and he will enter into the lands and sweep through like a flood.

question: According to Daniel 12:1-2, what will happen during "a time of distress such as has not been brought about since the nation began", and who will escape?

options.text: All humans are destroyed, without exception.

And Michael shall rise, and there shall be a time of great tribulation; and everyone that is found written in the book shall escape; and many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake, these to life unforeseen, and these to shame and abomination to unforeseen.
Only the nation of Israel will be saved, all other nations will be destroyed.
The world will be cleansed by a flood.

explanation: Daniel prophesies an unprecedented time of distress at the end of the system of things, during which Michael, the great prince (identified as Jesus Christ), will act in behalf of God's people, and those whose names are written in the "book of life" will be saved.
verseTextContent: “During that time Miʹcha·el will stand up, the great prince who is standing in behalf of your people. And there will occur a time of distress such as has not occurred since there came to be a nation until that time. And during that time your people will escape, everyone who is found written down in the book. And many of those asleep in the dust of the earth will wake up, some to everlasting life and others to reproach and to everlasting contempt.

question: How many horsemen are described in Revelation chapter 6 when the Lamb opens the first four seals?

options.text: Seven horsemen on horses of different colors.
Three horsemen, symbolizing war, famine and death.
Four horsemen: one on a white horse (Christ), one on a fire-colored horse (war), one on a black horse (hunger), and one on a pale horse (death).
A single rider on a white horse known as "the Word of God".

explanation: When the first four seals are opened, four symbolic horsemen appear in succession, the first on a white horse representing the victorious Christ, and the next represent war, famine, and death that characterize the "last days".
verseTextContent: And I saw when the Lamb opened one of the seven seals, and I heard one of the four living creatures say with a voice like thunder: “Come!” And I saw, and look! a white horse, and the one seated on it had a bow; and a crown was given him, and he went out conquering and to complete his conquest.

question: What city is described in Revelation as "the New Jerusalem" coming down from God from heaven?

options.text: The rebuilt earthly Jerusalem in the time of the Messiah.
A literal city of gold and precious stones on earth.
The "bride, the wife of the Lamb", is made up of 144,000 anointed Christians who will rule with Christ in heaven.
A symbol of heaven itself, where God dwells.

explanation: The New Jerusalem is not an earthly city, but symbolizes the glorified congregation of Christ's anointed followers (the 144,000), who will rule with him as his "bride" in the heavenly Kingdom and bring blessings to mankind on the restored earth.
verseTextContent: I also saw the holy city, New Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God and prepared as a bride adorned for her husband.

question: According to Revelation chapter 20, what will happen to Satan the Devil at the beginning of Christ's Millennial Reign?

options.text: It will be destroyed forever.
He will be thrown into the abyss and bound for a thousand years, so that he will no longer be able to mislead the nations.
He can continue to try on the people on earth.
He's converted and he's serving Christ.

explanation: Revelation describes that after Armageddon, an angel will seize Satan, bind him, and throw him into the abyss for the duration of Christ's Thousand Year Reign, when his misleading influence on mankind will be removed.
verseTextContent: And I saw an angel coming down out of heaven with the key of the abyss and a great chain in his hand. He seized the dragon, the original serpent, who is the Devil and Satan, and bound him for 1,000 years. And he hurled him into the abyss and shut it and sealed it over him, so that he would not mislead the nations anymore until the 1,000 years were ended. After this he must be released for a little while.

question: Who is "Babylon the Great", described in Revelation chapters 17 and 18 as a harlot riding on a scarlet-colored wild beast and having fornication with the kings of the earth?

options.text: The city of Rome in the time of the apostle John.
The world empire of false religion as a whole, which throughout history has compromised political powers and persecuted God's people.
A future global political superpower.
The materialist and consumer-oriented world society.

explanation: Jehovah's Witnesses view "Babylon the Great" as a symbol of all the world's false religions that have turned away from true worship of God. Their "fornication" with the "kings of the earth" represents their unholy alliances and compromises with political powers.
verseTextContent: And he carried me away in the power of the spirit into a wilderness. And I saw a woman sitting on a scarlet-colored wild beast that was full of blasphemous names and that had seven heads and ten horns. The woman was clothed in purple and scarlet, and she was adorned with gold and precious stones and pearls, and she had in her hand a golden cup that was full of disgusting things and the unclean things of her sexual immorality. On her forehead was written a name, a mystery: “Babylon the Great, the mother of the prostitutes and of the disgusting things of the earth.”

question: (Revelation 13:16-18) What is the "mark of the wild beast", and what are the consequences of accepting that mark?

options.text: A visible tattoo or an implanted microchip.

A symbolic sign representing submission to and worship of the world political system (the 'wild beast') and its militaristic 'image' by putting its ideology and rule over God's sovereignty, which leads to God's wrath being drawn upon one and not recorded in the 'Book of Life.'
Membership of a particular political party.
Paying taxes to the government.

explanation: The 'mark of the wild beast' is not a literal mark, but symbolizes identification with and support for the global political system controlled by Satan, which is to be shown loyalty and worship (recognition of its authority as the supreme good) rather than remaining faithful to God and his kingdom.
verseTextContent: It puts under compulsion all people—the small and the great, the rich and the poor, the free and the slaves—that these should be marked on their right hand or on their forehead, and that nobody can buy or sell except a person having the mark, the name of the wild beast or the number of its name.

question: (Revelation 7:9) What hope does this great crowd have, as Jehovah's Witnesses understand it?

options.text: They will rule with the 144,000 in heaven.

They come out of the "great tribulation", have made their robes white in the blood of the Lamb, and will gain everlasting life on a paradise earth under the rule of God's Kingdom, where God will dwell with them and wipe away every tear.
They represent all the people who have ever lived and are given a second chance.
They are angels serving God in heaven.

explanation: Jehovah's Witnesses view the "great crowd" as an innumerable crowd of people from all nations who will survive the great tribulation, exercising faith in Jesus' ransom sacrifice ("washing their robes in the blood of the Lamb") and having the prospect of everlasting life on a paradise earth with God's help to end all suffering.
verseTextContent: After this I saw, and look! a great crowd, which no man was able to number, out of all nations and tribes and peoples and tongues, standing before the throne and before the Lamb, dressed in white robes; and there were palm branches in their hands. And they keep shouting with a loud voice, saying: “Salvation we owe to our God, who is seated on the throne, and to the Lamb.”
